original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Northwestern Mutual, Underwriting Case Management, this is ________. How may I help you? SYM: Hi! This is Norm Weston calling from John Barrett's office. This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? Trainee: Hi Norm, may I start with a policy number to get started? SYM: This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? The policy number is T195129. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Give me one moment to pull up the case. Trainee: Thank you, Norm, I do have Marty's case pulled up here. You would like to talk about what will move this case to approval, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that is what I'm looking for. Trainee: Please give me a moment so I can review the details of the case and see what we can do to get this moving. SYM: Sounds good! Trainee: Thank you so much, I am all up to speed on this case. It looks like we are awaiting records from Dr. Smith's office and that a special authorization was sent to your office by the APS vendor to be reviewed. Do you have a copy of that completed form? SYM: No, I thought you sent it to the client and not just to me. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Let me take a moment to review the notes from our APS vendor to determine where the document was sent. SYM: Please do, I hope you sent it to the client. Trainee: It doesn't appear that this was sent directly to the client, instead it was sent to your office to facilitate that request. I can have that resent to you right away. SYM: Ok, that is fine. Do you really need these records though? It's been a long time. Trainee: It does look from the notes that the underwriter does require these notes in order to reach the final decision, however, I will put in a note requesting for a risk review and the underwriter will reach out with that information. In the meantime, I'll get the form over to you to reduce any further delay. SYM: That sounds fair. Thank you. Trainee: Of course. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all. Trainee: Awesome, well thank you so much for putting your trust in Northwestern Mutual. Have a great rest of your day. SYM: Thank you, you as well!

extraction.reason: Customer is asking why the underwriting case is taking so long and what the underwriter is waiting on, with the goal of moving the case toward approval.
steps: Ask for the policy number to locate the case in the system.
Pull up the case (policy T195129) and confirm that the customer wants to know what will move the case to approval.
Review case details to identify the delay: records from Dr. Smith's office and a special authorization form from the APS vendor.
Check whether the authorization form was sent to the client; determine it was sent to the office to facilitate the request, and offer to resend it to the client.
Note that the underwriter requires the records to reach a final decision, but place a note for a risk review and communicate that the underwriter will reach out with the information.
Provide the form to the client to help reduce further delay.
Close the conversation with courtesy and offer further assistance if needed.

original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation, you will assist the customer with setting up of automated gift for the child. Trainee: Hello, good afternoon. Thank you for calling Compassion. My name is [YOUR NAME]. How can I assist you today? SYM: Hi! I got a letter saying that my child is turning 16 today, and I thought I had to set up as an automated birthday gift. Every year he gets a birthday gift. Trainee: Thank you for being a sponsor and wanting to send a gift to your sponsored child. It's a wonderful way to show your care and support. SYM: Thank you. Do you want my account number or anything? Trainee: Yeah. May I know your sponsor number if you have it on hand? SYM: Yes, the number is X 1 Y 2 Z 3. Trainee: Thank you. Can you verify the first and last name on the account. SYM: Kim Reeves. Trainee: Alright, I have pulled up your account. And first, I would like to thank you for being part of Compassion since 2016 and for being a blessing to your two children. You do have Jim from Peru and Michael, that is from Rwanda. And with regards to the birthday gift, it looks like you haven’t setup a birthday gift here on the account. The only thing that you have set up is the automatic withdrawal for your monthly sponsorship for the birthday gift. SYM: Okay. Trainee: Regrettably, we don't have it here on the account. That means you didn't send a birthday gift to your child because you don't have any automatic set up of birthday gifts. SYM: Well, I thought it was already set up. So, if you could set it up today as an automatic gift and I can make a payment today on it. You need a card? Trainee: Let me check it here on the account. You do have here a visa card ending in 5252. Is it the one that you are using? SYM: Yeah, that one's good to use. Can you put it for $40? Automated birthday gift? Trainee: Yeah. Thank you so much for that. That would be $40 annually. And since we didn't receive one for today, we will be making one time birthday gift today. And then the next one would be on November 17, 2024, right? SYM: To do one today and the one in November? Trainee: Yes. Because it takes two to three months before it will be reflected on the account or it will be given to the child. Is it only for your child in Peru or are we going to set up for the one that is from Rwanda, for a month? SYM: I thought you said that one was already on automated. Trainee: It was on the automated, but you already sent one on last May 2023. You also sent one-time payment of a one-time birthday gift, but it wasn't setup on the automated payment. SYM: Let me just wait on that right now. When is his birthday again? Trainee: Yeah, it looks like your child's birthday, Michael is in July. Do you want to set it up today? SYM: Yeah, I'll do that a little bit later. I just wanted to get this one done today because I got an email that today was his birthday. I missed it. How long is it going to take for the area there to get this for him? Trainee: Yeah, it takes two to three months before they will be receiving the gift that you have sent to them. SYM: All right. Trainee: I'll just submit it here. So that would be the $40 pretty gift or annual pretty gift into the account. SYM: All right. And you have it set up as automated now, right? Trainee: Yes, that is correct. SYM: All right, thank you. Trainee: Everything is set now. Is there anything else I could help you with? SYM: No, that's it. I appreciate it. Trainee: Thank you for your time. Have a nice day. SYM: You too. Bye! SYM: This concludes your simulation.

Set up an automated birthday gift of $40 annually for the child and discussed the existing one-time gift in the context of automation.
Processed a one-time birthday gift today since the birthday occurred today and no gift had been received yet.
Noted that the gift delivery typically takes 2–3 months to reach the child and discussed the next scheduled date for the automated gift.
Confirmed that the automated birthday gift is now active and the customer understands the timeline.
Asked if there was anything else they needed help with and closed the call.

original_transcript: SYM: It’s closing time for this module. SYM: So, let’s recap all your learnings, move it to the phones. SYM: I hope you have learned something new. SYM: Throughout the call, you work hard to gain trust, establish credibility, discover needs, and utilize that information to find the right product for that caller’s needs. SYM: However, you can’t get the sale if you don’t ask! That’s the importance of closing. SYM: We should be asking for the sale immediately after providing the price. SYM: This is why a best practice during the discover process is to ask the budget question last, because it is a natural transition to price. SYM: By asking the budget question last, you are in a better position to successfully close because you have all your information you need to know to offer the right product based on the customers needs. SYM: There are multiple closing techniques you can use. SYM: Find the one that works best for your personality and call style. SYM: You don’t have to use the same one every time, don’t be afraid to step outside your comfort zone and try something new! SYM: Hearing no can and will happen to everyone in a sales role. SYM: There is not a closing technique that guarantees everyone will say yes. SYM: Remember to catch it, catch it, change it when it comes to hearing no on calls. SYM: You will hear more no’s than yes’s and that’s okay. SYM: So don’t be afraid to go for no - that means you at least asked for the sale! SYM: It’s officially closing time, open all the queues and let you out into those calls!

extraction.reason: This is a training module focused on closing sales; no specific customer issue was discussed.
steps: Gain trust and establish credibility with the caller.
Discover the caller's needs and gather relevant information.
Utilize the gathered information to identify the right product for the caller.
Present price after outlining options and value.
Ask for the sale (close) immediately after providing the price.
Use budget information strategically by asking the budget question last to facilitate a natural transition to price.
Choose and apply closing techniques that fit your personality and call style.
Anticipate and handle objections; expect no answers, and 'catch it, change it' when needed.
Be proactive and willing to try different closing approaches to increase the chances of a sale.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Xfinity Mobile, we appreciate your business. This is (YOUR NAME). May I have your name please? SYM: My name is Danerra Lamburth. Trainee: How about the last four digits of the credit or debit card on file? SYM: 4 9 8 0 Trainee: Thank you, Danerra, for providing all the necessary information to access your account. Your cooperation is appreciated. I was able to pull up your account, and I can see that you have two iPhone devices. May I know the mobile number of the device on which you would like to activate the new SIM card? SYM: (560) 346-9876 Trainee: To ensure that I got the correct number, which is (560) 346-9876, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that's correct. Trainee: Nice! How about the ICCID number of the new SIM card? SYM: Where can I find that? Trainee: The ICCID for your Xfinity Mobile SIM card can typically be found printed on the SIM card itself or on the SIM card packaging. It is a unique 20-digit number that identifies your SIM card. If you're unable to locate the ICCID on the SIM card or packaging, you can find it in the settings of your phone once it's inserted. On your iPhone, go to Settings > General > About. The entry titled ICCID is your SIM card number. SYM: I found it! The number is too small on the card. That is 8 9 1 4 8 0 0 0 0 0 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0. Trainee: To confirm, it is 89148000009876543210, am I right? SYM: Yes. Trainee: Thank you for confirming it. Let me go ahead and update the new SIM card on your phone. This may take a few minutes to complete the process, and I'll be asking you to reset the network settings of your phone afterwards. SYM: Sure. Take your time. Trainee: Okay, here's what I found out, Danerra. Your SIM card is not activated because of the pending order on the account. And this needs to be completed before your SIM card can be activated. SYM: It's been three days; I am confused as to why my phone is still not working, and is this the only reason why? Trainee: So please give me a moment while I am working on it. I will let you know once the pending order is completed and to activate the SIM card. SYM: Sure, take your time. Trainee: All right, Danerra. I was able to activate and update your new SIM card. Kindly insert the new SIM card and reset the network settings on your phone. Before that, I would like to set your expectation that any saved Wi-Fi networks and passwords will be removed and all paired devices will be unpaired. So, after you reset the network settings, please set up your phone so everything will be connected again. Just go to Settings > General > Reset. Then select "Reset Network Settings" and confirm your choice when prompted. After the reset, your phone will restart. Please test the call functionality afterwards. SYM: I already inserted the SIM card and reset the network settings. My phone is restarting now. Trainee: Once your phone is back on, please check the network connectivity and let me know if everything is working as expected. SYM: Sure, I will. Trainee: While your phone is restarting, I'd like to express my gratitude for being a valued [Silver, Gold, Platinum, or Premium] customer with Xfinity Rewards. As a loyal customer, you have access to exciting rewards and exclusive benefits. The longer you stay with us, the more rewards you can enjoy. You can conveniently access your rewards anytime through the Xfinity app or by visiting www.xfinity.com/rewards. SYM: Thank you. Trainee: Thank you, Danerra! Your loyalty means a lot to us. Don't forget to make the most of the rewards we offer. We have a range of exclusive benefits and perks specifically tailored for customers like you. If you ever have any questions or need assistance in maximizing your rewards, feel free to ask. We're here to help! SYM: I appreciate you sharing that. And I just tested the network, and it's working perfectly now! Thank you for your assistance. Trainee: You're most welcome, Danerra. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all I needed. I really appreciate your prompt and efficient support. Trainee: It's a collaboration with you! Just for a quick recap, you contacted Xfinity today to activate your new SIM card, which is now working as a replacement for the number ending in 9876. Then I asked you to insert the SIM card and reset the network settings. You confirmed that everything is working after testing it. SYM: Thank you so much! Trainee: It's been a pleasure taking care of your needs today, and I appreciate your collaboration and patience while we resolved your issue. Thank you, and have a great rest of your day! SYM: Thanks, you too! SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: Customer needed assistance activating a new Xfinity Mobile SIM card that was not yet activated.
steps: Greeted the customer and obtained permission to access the account for security.
Collected security details (billing address on file and last four digits of the card) to verify identity.
Accessed the account and identified the line to activate the new SIM card (the number ending in 9876).
Asked for the ICCID of the new SIM card and guided the customer on where to find it; customer provided the ICCID and it was confirmed.
Identified that activation was blocked due to a pending order on the account.
Activated and updated the new SIM card in the account and informed the customer the process may take a few minutes and that a network reset would be required.
Instructed the customer to insert the new SIM card and reset the network settings, warning that saved Wi‑Fi networks/passwords would be removed and devices would be unpaired.
Customer confirmed they had inserted the SIM and performed the reset; instructed to test network connectivity after the restart.
Customer tested and reported that the network was working; provided a closing recap and appreciation.

original_transcript: SYM: Congratulations on running your first sym. Now lets see how you did. From here you can already see your Completion Time, Keyword and Click score. SYM: Keywords are structure words in the the conversation that are good word choices or can even be compliance words that must be said. If the sym has no agent lines you will not have a keyword score. Click score is scoring where on the visual components of the sym you navigated and clicked through during the process. Click score will only be in visual syms. SYM: All of the playbacks for every sym you execute will always be in Playback on the left side of the screen, last tab, with the headphone icon. SYM: For now, Click the Green View Playback button to see more detail on how you did. SYM: Starting at the top left, you can see every attempt you have completed of this sym, and the playback for each. This allows you to see how you are improving with each attempt. SYM: You can also see if you completed it in Practice or Test Mode, the day and time completed, and you can even click re-attempt and do it again. SYM: Next you will see your Sym Accuracy Score. This measures how well your response matched the intent of what the customer was asking in the customer script line. If this is a beginner sym your score should be in the 90% range, because you would have said the script line pretty close to word for word, to learn the intent. In Intermediate and Advanced Syms, when you are formulating your own words, this score might go down, but you want to aim for the 80-90% range, so that your intent is matching the need of the customer as closely as possible. If your sym has no agent lines you will not have a sym accuracy score. SYM: Completion time is important because if it is taking you longer to navigate the conversation and screens, it can be an indication that you just need to practice the beginner sym more to learn the process better. It won't take long before you will know exactly what to do. Keep practicing. SYM: The first number in the keyword score is your score, and the second is the possible score. Keywords are structure words that are good word choices you will want to say, or they can even be compliance words you must say. Keywords guide you to the best and fastest way to customer resolution and satisfaction. SYM: The first number in the click score is your score, and the second is the possible score. Click scores are the places on the screens where you clicked, and it scored you if you clicked in the correct place. SYM: The Sym Score will equal a combined score of the different scoring options. If a sym has all three, Sym Accuracy, Keyword and Click Score, the sym score will be total of all, as one sym score. If a sym has two or only one of these scoring options, the sym score will equal the total of only the scoring options used in that sym. SYM: Text Field Keyword score will appear if the sym was created with keywords in the Text Fields that can be put into visual syms. A best practice is to always enter text into those fields exactly as directed because you never know if that text will be a keyword or not until you finish. SYM: Confidence, Concentration and Energy are your sentiment scores. These scores are calculated by the level of intent you deliver the script line in the areas of confidence, concentration and energy. These are not calculated on your voice or tone, but on how confident your level of intent is, how your focus or concentration level and how your pace or energy level of intent is. The sentiment score is calculated for the entire sym, not one part or another. SYM: The measurement for sentiment scores will be High, Medium or Low, and you can click the insights to learn more about what you did well, and what you can do to improve. SYM: As a reminder you will not receive a sentiment score in your practice attempts, only in your test attempts, and if your sym has no agent lines, you will not have a sentiment score. SYM: The playback also allows you to listen to a recording of you executing the sym. You can click a script line below and the recording will skip to that part of the recording if you wanted to only listen to a certain part. SYM: If you see a dot in the recording like this, this is the Text Field Key Word Score we just talked about. This will show you if you got that word or if you missed it. As you can see I missed it because it is red, and it gave me the correct response. SYM: The bottom part of the playback page is the actual script. The highlighted words are the keywords. If they are green I got them. If they are red I missed them. You will also notice the KS and SA and then a number score, like 3/4 and a percent, such as 86%. These are your Keyword Scores and Sym Accuracy scores by script line. The first number in the keyword score is your score and the second is the possible score. The Sym Accuracy score tells you how you did in this line with intent compared to the customer script line you were responding to. SYM: This gives you the ability to see exactly in the sym where you can improve on keywords and sym accuracy. The total Sym Accuracy and Keyword scores at the top are a total of these by script line totals. SYM: And finally you will always see the scripted line with the keywords you said or did not say vs what you said in response. The default is to show both, but you can toggle that off if you want to just see the scripted line and the keywords you said or did not say. SYM: Great Job! This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: This transcript is a training/diagnostic guide about evaluating a Sym performance, not a real customer issue.
steps: Explain the metrics that appear for a sym: Completion Time, Keyword Score, Click Score, Sym Accuracy Score, and sentiment scores.
Describe what each metric means (e.g., keywords are structure words; click score tracks where you clicked; accuracy measures alignment with the customer script).
Tell the user where to access playback: the left-side Playback panel, last tab with the headphone icon.
Instruct to click the Green View Playback button to view detailed playback for each attempt.
Show how to review attempts: top-left shows each attempt, mode (Practice/Test), date/time, and the option to re-attempt.
Explain Sym Accuracy Score target ranges: beginner around 90%, intermediate/advanced may dip when formulating own words but aim for 80-90%.
Highlight the importance of Completion Time as a performance indicator and encourage practice if it’s slow.
Explain the scoring format: the first number is your score and the second is the possible score for Keyword and Click scores.
Clarify that the Sym Score is the sum of the contributing components (Sym Accuracy, Keyword, Click Score) that are present for a given sym.
Describe Text Field Keyword Score: if present, you should copy the required text exactly as directed because it may be a keyword.

Explain sentiment scores (Confidence, Concentration, Energy): how they reflect intent and focus, not voice tone; they apply to the whole sym and are shown only in test attempts (or when there are agent lines).
Explain how to use playback controls to listen to specific parts by script line, and what the color-coding (green vs red) and dots indicate regarding keywords.
Note that the bottom playback shows the script line with the keywords you said vs the scripted line, and that you can toggle this display.

original_transcript: SYM: You have already opened the call and verified customer details. In this simulation, you will gather information and resolve the customer's concern. SYM: STEP 2 - Gather Information. Trainee: Thank you, Ash. Let me pull up your policy information. While I do that, could you please provide me with the details of the medical procedure you're inquiring about? SYM: I'm considering getting a knee surgery called arthroscopic meniscectomy. I wanted to know if it's covered under my policy. Trainee: I understand. Let me check the specifics of your coverage. Just give me a moment, please. Trainee: Thank you for waiting, Ash. I have reviewed your policy, and I can confirm that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered under your health insurance plan. However, it's important to note that coverage can vary based on factors such as medical necessity, network providers, and any applicable deductibles or co-payments. SYM: That's great to hear! Could you please provide me with some additional information? For instance, do I need a referral from my primary care physician before scheduling the surgery? Trainee: That's an excellent question, Ash. According to your policy, you do not require a referral from your primary care physician for this specific procedure. However, it's always a good idea to consult with your doctor or surgeon to ensure that the surgery is appropriate for your specific medical condition. SYM: I see. Thank you for clarifying that. Now, I'm also curious about the coverage limits and any out-of-pocket expenses I may incur. Trainee: Certainly, Ash. Let me go over that with you. Your policy has a coverage limit for surgical procedures, and I can see that it includes coverage for this specific surgery. As for out-of-pocket expenses, it's important to review your policy documents or contact our claims department to determine any deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance that may apply. SYM: I'll make sure to review my policy documents. Lastly, could you provide me with a list of in-network surgeons or facilities that perform this procedure? Trainee: Absolutely, Ash. I can assist you with that. Please bear with me while I access the network provider information. SYM: No worries. Trainee: Thank you for your patience, Ash. I have compiled a list of in-network surgeons and facilities that perform arthroscopic meniscectomy in your area. I will email you the list to the email address we have on file. Additionally, you can also visit our website or contact our customer service line to obtain this information. SYM: That's perfect. Thank you so much for your help. You've been very informative. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

Explain potential coverage limits for surgical procedures and discuss possible out-of-pocket expenses (deductibles, co-payments, coinsurance), advising to review policy documents or contact claims for specifics.

Offer to email the in-network list to the customer and mention additional ways to obtain it (website or customer service line).
Provide reassurance and close the interaction.

original_transcript: SYM: In this sym, we will review how the UCSL application varies based on state. SYM: Reminder that we can not C O P whole life applications for Connecticut or Montana. SYM: New York has its own application for our Guaranteed Whole Life policy. We’ll go into detail on New York later. SYM: The states in red on the map have some different verbatim messages that will appear in the e App. SYM: Remember that these boxes are verbatim statements. SYM: You should not try to memorize these, as they may change for each state. SYM: Always be sure to read what's on your screen word for word. SYM: One such example is with California, the final application verbatim has an additional paragraph regarding fraud. SYM: This allows us to be compliant with California law. The fraud statement is also provided in the policy documents. SYM: Again, this is why you should not memorize verbatims. Simply follow the application. SYM: Another California law requires we obtain an email address from our California elders (which is age 65 or older) so we can send them pertinent disclosures before the application is completed. SYM: To comply with the California law, there is a verbatim early in the application regarding consent to electronic delivery and e-signature. SYM: The verbatim and email address field is mandatory, and the e-app will prevent you from continuing the application if you do not enter in a valid customer email address. SYM: Once you have entered the email address in the box you must press the Send button. If you don’t press this button, the e-app will prevent you from continuing the application. SYM: If the email fails to send, the Send button will turn red and will say Fail. SYM: The e-app will prevent you from moving forward until an email has successfully been sent. SYM: If the email successfully sends, the Send button will turn green and will say Sent. SYM: Once you have received the green Sent message, you need to ask the customer to verbally confirm they received the email. SYM: This is what the email that the customer receives looks like. SYM: Here’s another question that will only appear during the application in certain states. SYM: These states have state special questions and verbiage that is required to be read about accessing PDF files via the internet and providing their consent to receive electronic documents. SYM: The state requires we review this electronic consent. SYM: We're asking if they can access the internet in any shape or form. SYM: If they say no, you can clarify by asking if they have access to the internet (smart phone, library, etc.). SYM: If they still answer No, you will need to explain to the applicant that if they are not able to access the internet, or do not provide their consent, you will not be able to take their application over the phone and it will need to be mailed to them. This may delay the processing time and the effective date of their policy. SYM: Let’s practice a state specific scenario! Click the arrow when you are ready to begin. Trainee: Have you received an application packet? SYM: No. Trainee: Are you able to open, view and save P D F files via the internet? SYM: No. Trainee: Do you have access to the internet by using a smart phone or going to the library? SYM: Oh, yes. I can do that. Trainee: I am required to obtain your consent for the delivery of electronic documents to you whether through the internet, email, web, text, instant message, digital media or the like. Your consent applies to all documents Mutual of Omaha may be required to deliver to you in writing. Any document provided to you electronically may be provided in paper upon your request. You may withdraw your consent at any time. If you withdraw your consent, I will not be able to complete your application over the phone and I will need to mail you a paper application. You may withdraw your consent, update your contact information or obtain a paper copy of any document for no charge, by contacting (800) 775-6000. You will need access to a computer or other device which provides internet access or email, as well as the ability to open, view and save a PDF, text or html file. Trainee: Do I have your consent to provide you with the necessary documents electronically? SYM: Yes Trainee: Disclosures are made available to you at the following website: http://www.mutualofomaha.com/wholelifedocuments SYM: Great job practicing one of those state specific items in the e App. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Understanding that the e App will vary by state ensures compliance with state-specific rules and regulations, helping us navigate the process accurately and effectively.

extraction.reason: To learn how the UCSL e-App varies by state and how to handle state-specific requirements (verbatim messages, fraud/disclosure rules, electronic delivery consent, and internet access questions).
steps: Explain that the e-App varies by state and identify states with unique requirements (e.g., Connecticut, Montana, New York, California).
Emphasize that state-specific verbatim messages appear on screen and must be read exactly as shown; do not memorize them.
Describe California-specific items, including an additional fraud paragraph and the elder email collection requirement for consent to electronic delivery and e-signature.
Explain the mandatory email address field, the requirement to press Send, and how the app blocks progression until a successful email is sent (red 'Fail' and green 'Sent' indicators).
Instruct to verify with the customer, after the email shows as Sent, that they verbally received the email.
Cover any state-specific questions about accessing PDFs via the internet and obtaining consent to receive electronic documents.
Ask the customer if they have internet access (via computer, smartphone, library, etc.); clarify how to proceed if they say no.

If the customer cannot access the internet or does not consent, explain that the application cannot be completed over the phone and must be mailed, which may delay processing and the policy effective date.
Practice a state-specific scenario with the trainee to apply the rules, and recap the key learnings.

original_transcript: SYM: Hello and welcome to our ABC BackOffice tool training. Here, we will learn how to create a prescription request for a client. All the data that you will enter in this simulation is sample data. This is a practice sym, once you get on a live call, the data will be based on the interactions with the caller. SYM: You will first enter the customer’s contact reason in the highlighted fields. SYM: Now, you'll write the customer's full name by clicking on the First Name and Last Name fields on the page. SYM: After entering the customer's full name, click on search. SYM: You will now validate the customer's date of birth for security verification purposes. SYM: You will now search for the name of the medication the customer is looking to get a prescription for. Use the sample data as advised. SYM: Once you've found the medication details in the system, you'll confirm with the customer if they have ever been prescribed this medication when you take a live call. SYM: Subsequently, you'll write down the dosage and quantity of the medication requested by the customer on a live call. SYM: Write in the customer's complete address with the zip code in the required fields. SYM: For the delivery process, you'll check the options available in the Delivery dropdown and choose accordingly. SYM: Finally, enter the primary healthcare provider's name and phone number. SYM: Once you have entered all the details, you'll click on Save to record the information and the task will be completed and assigned. SYM: Good job! You have now completed training on "How to create a prescription request for a customer". Click on the screen to finish and wait for your trainer to give you further instructions. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

Confirm with the customer if they have ever been prescribed this medication on a live call
Write down the dosage and quantity of the medication requested by the customer

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Northwestern Mutual, Underwriting Case Management, this is ________. How may I help you? SYM: Hi! This is Norm Weston calling from John Barrett's office. This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? Trainee: Hi Norm, may I start with a policy number to get started? SYM: This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? The policy number is T195129. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Give me one moment to pull up the case. Trainee: Thank you, Norm, I do have Marty's case pulled up here. You would like to talk about what will move this case to approval, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that is what I'm looking for. Trainee: Please give me a moment so I can review the details of the case and see what we can do to get this moving. SYM: Sounds good! Trainee: Thank you so much, I am all up to speed on this case. It looks like we are awaiting records from Dr. Smith's office and that a special authorization was sent to your office by the APS vendor to be reviewed. Do you have a copy of that completed form? SYM: No, I thought you sent it to the client and not just to me. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Let me take a moment to review the notes from our APS vendor to determine where the document was sent. SYM: Please do, I hope you sent it to the client. Trainee: It doesn't appear that this was sent directly to the client, instead it was sent to your office to facilitate that request. I can have that resent to you right away. SYM: Ok, that is fine. Do you really need these records though? It's been a long time. Trainee: It does look from the notes that the underwriter does require these notes in order to reach the final decision, however, I will put in a note requesting for a risk review and the underwriter will reach out with that information. In the meantime, I'll get the form over to you to reduce any further delay. SYM: That sounds fair. Thank you. Trainee: Of course. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all. Trainee: Awesome, well thank you so much for putting your trust in Northwestern Mutual. Have a great rest of your day. SYM: Thank you, you as well!

Confirm that the goal is to move the case toward approval
Review case details and identify what the underwriter is waiting on (records from Dr. Smith's office and APS special authorization)
Ask if the customer has a copy of the completed APS form
Check where the APS form was sent; determine it was sent to the office, not the client
Offer to resend the APS form to the client to reduce further delay

original_transcript: SYM: Hello! If you are starting this sym, that means you chose the Empathy Close as the technique you would like to try on your calls. ​ If you wanted to try a different closing technique, now is the time to exit this sym and head to the one you wanted to practice. SYM: Here are a few tips for how to navigate throughout this Sym. SYM: [sighing loudly] Trainee: So, the reason the funds haven’t processed yet is that your e-mail address is not registered. SYM: No way. I DID give my email. original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation, you will help a customer identify whether a procedure is covered by their health insurance. SYM: STEP 1 - Opening. SYM: [Phone rings] Trainee: Thank you for calling ABC Health Insurance. My name is [YOUR NAME]. How may I assist you today? SYM: Hi, my name is Ash. I wanted to inquire if a specific medical procedure is covered by my health insurance. Trainee: Of course, Ash. I'm here to help. May I have your first and last name? SYM: Ash Harris. Trainee: I appreciate it. Can you please provide me with your policy number so that I can access your account? SYM: Sure, my policy number is A B C 1 2 3 4 5 6. SYM: STEP 2 - Gather Information. Trainee: Thank you, Ash. Let me pull up your policy information. While I do that, could you please provide me with the details of the medical procedure you're inquiring about? SYM: I'm considering getting a knee surgery called arthroscopic meniscectomy. I wanted to know if it's covered under my policy. Trainee: I understand. Let me check the specifics of your coverage. Just give me a moment, please. Trainee: Thank you for waiting, Ash. I have reviewed your policy, and I can confirm that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered under your health insurance plan. However, it's important to note that coverage can vary based on factors such as medical necessity, network providers, and any applicable deductibles or co-payments. SYM: That's great to hear! Could you please provide me with some additional information? For instance, do I need a referral from my primary care physician before scheduling the surgery? Trainee: That's an excellent question, Ash. According to your policy, you do not require a referral from your primary care physician for this specific procedure. However, it's always a good idea to consult with your doctor or surgeon to ensure that the surgery is appropriate for your specific medical condition. SYM: I see. Thank you for clarifying that. Now, I'm also curious about the coverage limits and any out-of-pocket expenses I may incur. Trainee: Certainly, Ash. Let me go over that with you. Your policy has a coverage limit for surgical procedures, and I can see that it includes coverage for this specific surgery. As for out-of-pocket expenses, it's important to review your policy documents or contact our claims department to determine any deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance that may apply. SYM: I'll make sure to review my policy documents. Lastly, could you provide me with a list of in-network surgeons or facilities that perform this procedure? Trainee: Absolutely, Ash. I can assist you with that. Please bear with me while I access the network provider information. SYM: No worries. Trainee: Thank you for your patience, Ash. I have compiled a list of in-network surgeons and facilities that perform arthroscopic meniscectomy in your area. I will email you the list to the email address we have on file. Additionally, you can also visit our website or contact our customer service line to obtain this information. SYM: That's perfect. Thank you so much for your help. You've been very informative. SYM: STEP 3 - Closing. Trainee: You're welcome. Can you confirm your email address for me? SYM: That would be Ash@email.com Trainee: Thank you, Ash. I'm glad I could assist you. If you have any further questions or need any additional information, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you make the most of your health insurance coverage. SYM: I appreciate that. Thanks again for your assistance. Trainee: It's my pleasure, Ash. Take care, and have a great day! SYM: This concludes your simulation.

Step 2 - Policy lookup and coverage check: Retrieved policy information and confirmed that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered, noting that coverage can vary by medical necessity, network providers, deductibles, and co-pays.
Step 3 - Clarified referral requirement: Informed the customer that no referral from a primary care physician is required for this procedure, while advising consultation with their doctor or surgeon.

original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation, you will assist the customer to update their new card on the account for automatic payment plan. Trainee: Hello, thank you for calling Compassion. My name is [YOUR NAME]. And how can I help you? SYM: Yes, I just got a notice from Compassion that my credit card is expiring. I just wanted to put a new credit card on file. Trainee: Sure! Well, thank you so much for giving us a call today. Let me help you to set up your new card information onto your account. Let me pull up your account first. May I know your name on the account, please? SYM: It's Lisa Turner, and I may need to change my address on my account as well. Trainee: Definitely, I can also help you with that. So, we can change the address first. Then afterwards we can update your payment information, too. SYM: Sure. Trainee: So, I do have now your account as 124578. I also wanted to thank you for being a blessing to a child. SYM: Thanks. Trainee: So, before we update your payment information, let me help you to change your address. So, what we have here on file is 110 Riverside Coral FL 33071. SYM: That is correct, yes. Trainee: So, may I have then your updated address, please? SYM: No, I don't need to. It sounds like it has been updated. Trainee: Great! So, let's proceed with updating of your payment information. Just give me a few moments here. SYM: Okay. Trainee: I see that for your monthly payment plan, you were set up using your American Express card ending in 5500 and I see that it's about to expire. So, expiration date is December of 2023. SYM: Correct. Trainee: So, you'll be setting up for a new card or a totally different card? SYM: Yes. It's a new American Express card with a different card number. Trainee: Okay, so let's start to set up your new card information. SYM: Okay. Trainee: To setup your new card and also for the safety of it, I'll be transferring you to our secure line where all you have to do is just simply enter the card number over the phone, and again this call will be routed back to me. Would that be, okay? SYM: Sure. Thanks. Trainee: So, I'll be transferring you now. SYM: Sure! SYM: [Customer enters the new card number over the phone.] Trainee: Yes, thank you so much. I do have now your American Express card ending in 2005. And can you please confirm the card's expiration date? SYM: It is eight of 28. Trainee: And how does your name appear on this card? SYM: Lisa J Turner. Trainee: Thank you. So, let me set up your new card information for your automatic monthly payment plan. Give me a few moments here. SYM: Sure. I believe they have already drafted out for this month, correct? Trainee: Yes, that is correct. It was drafted on December 19. SYM: Okay. Trainee: Thank you so much for patiently waiting, Miss Turner. I have set up your new card information for your automatic monthly payment which would be starting from next month. The date is set for every 19th day of each month. SYM: Perfect! Trainee: Thank you for your time calling us. And was there anything else that I can help you for today? SYM: No, that's it. I appreciate that and thank you. Trainee: You're welcome, Miss Turner. You have a great day! SYM: You as well. Bye! SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: Customer requested to update the payment method on file due to card expiration and ensure future automatic payments use the new card.
steps: Identify the account owner (Lisa Turner) and pull up the account details.
Check if the address needed updating; verify the address on file and obtain confirmation that no change is needed.
Review the existing payment method on file (American Express ending in 5500) and note its expiration (Dec 2023).
Confirm the customer wants to switch to a new card for automatic payments.
Transfer the customer to a secure line to collect the new card number securely.
Enter and confirm the new card details (American Express ending in 2005; expiration 08/28; name on card Lisa J Turner).
Set up the automatic monthly payment to use the new card starting next month and schedule payments on the 19th of each month; confirm the current month's draft occurred on Dec 19.
Close the call and confirm no additional help is needed.

original_transcript: SYM: You were about to begin a simulation Please click the United logo to begin Trainee: Good morning Mrs. McCann, I see you are calling about confirmation number F7SBF8. Is that correct? SYM: Yes, I am I wanted to review my options to take a later flight Trainee: OK, let me check your options. Trainee: Based on the Basic Economy fare, you can not make changes to your reservation. SYM: Yes, I understand I can't make any changes to my ticket, but I'm booked at 1:00 o'clock PM and I need to leave on the 5:50 PM flight instead What am I on? Flight instead What are my options? Trainee: That's a good question, let's check. Trainee: Since there is a $200 change fee plus the difference in fare let me look what booking a new flight from Chicago O'Hare to Atlanta as an option for you. SYM: OK, great if it's less than $200, that may be a great idea Trainee: Wow, Mrs. McCann I found the flight you are looking for at 5:50pm from Chicago O'Hare to Atlanta for $106 plus a $25 non-refundable booking fee. Would you like me to book that for you? SYM: That's great, let me check and see if that helps and I can book it online Trainee: No problem. Thank you for calling United Airlines and make it a great day. SYM: This completes the simulation

extraction.reason: Customer wanted to review options to depart on a later flight (changing from the 1:00 PM flight to a 5:50 PM flight) while on a Basic Economy fare.
steps: Verify the customer's request to switch from the 1:00 PM ORD-ATL flight to a 5:50 PM flight and confirm the reservation details.
Explain that Basic Economy fare cannot be used to make changes to the existing reservation.
Propose an alternative: book a new flight (since changes aren’t allowed) and explain there would be a $200 change fee plus any fare difference.
Search for a suitable ORD-ATL option and consider the 5:50 PM departure as the desired alternative.
Identify a 5:50 PM ORD-ATL option priced at $106 plus a $25 non-refundable booking fee.
Offer to book the new flight and ask for confirmation to proceed.
Customer indicates they will review and that online booking is possible.

original_transcript: SYM: Welcome back! Congratulations on completing your first sym a moment ago. Now let’s see how you did. SYM: Before we get started, I want to draw your attention to the sym time length on the opening screen of each sym. SYM: This lets you know on average how long it should take to complete the sym. SYM: Take a moment to look for the “Time Elapsed” located at the top of this sym. SYM: As you work through syms, be sure to keep an eye on your pace so you can finish within the allotted time for the assignment. SYM: Let’s proceed full steam ahead! SYM: Reminder, here are some best practices for navigating throughout a sym. Click the arrow when you are ready to continue. SYM: After completing a sym, you will be directed to a screen that looks like this. SYM: From here you can already see your Completion Time, Keyword Score, and Click Score. SYM: To view more details on your sym score, click View Playback. SYM: This playback view provides more insight on your performance. SYM: You can see if you completed the sym in Practice or Test Mode, the day and time completed, and you can even click re-attempt and do it again from here. SYM: Here is that completion time again. SYM: Completion time is important because if it is taking you longer to navigate the conversation and screens, it can be an indication that you just need to practice the sym more to learn the process better. SYM: Let’s break down the other stats on the screen, starting with Keyword Score. SYM: Keywords are structure words in the conversation that are good word choices or can even be compliance words that must be said. If the sym has no agent lines, you will not have a keyword score. SYM: The DSC is not a scripted environment. The key words chosen throughout the syms will be ones that everyone should say. SYM: For example, everyone should state “Mutual of Omaha” in your call introduction. SYM: The first number is your keyword score, and the second is the possible score. SYM: In that last sym, I got 3 out of 4 keywords correct. SYM: To see which one I missed, I can scroll down to find it in the playback. SYM: Words highlighted green indicate you got the keyword correct, while red indicates it was missed. SYM: Here I can see that I missed the first word, hello. SYM: You can click the Trainee Response to jump to that part of the recording, then click Play to listen. SYM: After listening to my playback, I could here that I said hello, but the microphone didn’t start picking up right away so the greeting was cut off. SYM: Technology is not perfect. There could also be times where it thought you said a different word. For example, application and occupation can sound similar to a computer. SYM: That is why the training team and your supervisors review playback on lower scoring syms. SYM: This allows them to see if it was a system error or a coaching opportunity. SYM: Scroll back to the top to look at the rest of the sym score. SYM: Let’s review Click Score next. SYM: Click Score is scoring where on the visual components of the sym you navigated and clicked through during the process. Click score will only be in visual syms. SYM: The first number is your click score, and the second is the possible score. SYM: In that last sym, I got 19 out of 19 clicks correct. Way to go me! That is a good indicator that I understand the process in the sym. SYM: Confidence, Concentration and Energy are your sentiment scores. SYM: These scores are calculated by the level of intent you deliver the script line in the areas of confidence, concentration and energy. SYM: These are not calculated on your voice or tone, but on how confident your level of intent is, your focus or concentration level, and your pace or energy level. SYM: The sentiment score is calculated for the entire sym, not one part or another. SYM: My Energy score was Medium. I can click Insights to view more. SYM: This is where I can find insight on how to improve that score if I were to take it again, or helpful advice for future syms. SYM: Next let’s look at the Sym Accuracy Score. SYM: This measures how well your response matched the intent of what the customer was asking in the customer script line. SYM: SymTrain is still working on improvements to the Sym Accuracy score, and this is being monitored by the training team at the moment. SYM: The final stat to look at is the Sym Score. SYM: This will equal a combined score of the different scoring options for that sym. If this is a beginner sym your score should be in the 80% range. SYM: Again, technology is not perfect. That is why the training team and supervisors will take a look at those lower scores to see if it was a system error or a coaching opportunity for improvement. SYM: Now that we’ve reviewed how to look at detailed playback after completing a sym, let’s head to the Playback page. SYM: The Playback page provides an overview of your sym performance for all your completed syms. SYM: To view the detailed playback for any sym, simply click the Actions icon. SYM: This concludes the simulation. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Fantastic job completing SymTrain 1 0 1! You are ready to continue your learning journey and start taking syms! Bon voyage!

extraction.reason: The user needs guidance on understanding Sym performance metrics and playback after completing a SymTrain exercise.
steps: Point out where to find Time Elapsed and Completion Time on the opening screen and explain why pace matters.
Tell the user to click View Playback to access detailed performance data.
Explain that the Playback view shows if the sym was completed in Practice or Test Mode, the day and time completed, and the option to re-attempt.
Describe Completion Time as an indicator of navigation pace and potential need for more practice.
Review Keyword Score: explain the two numbers, how green means the keyword was correct and red means it was missed, and show how to click Trainee Response to jump to and listen to the relevant part.
Note that technology can misinterpret words and that the training team may review playback for coaching opportunities.
Explain Click Score: how the score reflects navigation and clicks within visual syms, and that it is shown as a ratio (e.g., 19 out of 19).
Discuss sentiment scores (Confidence, Concentration, Energy): explain they reflect intent, focus, and pace, not voice tone, and show how to view insights for improvement.
Explain Sym Accuracy Score and that the final Sym Score combines multiple components; mention that accuracy scoring is being refined.
Describe the Sym Score as the overall performance measure and the typical expectation for beginners (around the 80s percentage).
Show how to use the Playback page to review all completed syms and how to access detailed playback for a specific sym via the Actions icon, including re-attempt options.
Encourage continuing to the next sym and applying the insights gained from playback and insights.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Walmart Customer Relations, my name is [Your Name]. With whom I have the pleasure to speak with? SYM: Hi, my name is John Johnson. Trainee: Nice to meet you John, how are you today? SYM: Fine and you? Trainee: I'm fine as well, thanks for asking. Let me know John, how can I assist you today? SYM: Yes, I purchased a car seat stroller combo for my daughter-in-law, and it's not the right one, and I misplaced the receipt. SYM: I went to the store and they told me to call you guys that you can help me locate it because I paid for cash with it. Trainee: Thanks John, and do you know the store ZIP code or the store number you made the purchase on? SYM: Yes, the store number is 1 5 8 4. Trainee: Just to confirm I have the right store, is this the Super Center on Rainbow 3615? SYM: Correct, that is the one. Trainee: Thanks John, and could you please tell me if you remember the day of the purchase? SYM: I do know that I purchased it in February. I'm not sure the exact date, but I believe it was during the first two weeks in February, if I'm not mistaken. Trainee: Okay, thank you John. So, you told me it was with cash, do you remember how much was the total amount of the receipt? SYM: The car seat stroller combo was around $199. So, I want to say I know I didn't spend no more than 350 so maybe search 250 to 350 dollars. Trainee: Okay, so let me search for the receipt information right now based on the description provided. Allow a moment. Trainee: I can see I found one that matches your description. Was the item you are lookng for the "Sonar Switch 6 in 1 Modular Stroller Travel Sytems"? SYM: That is correct, that is the one. How much was that one? Trainee: The car seat combo was $159. SYM: Great, that is the one. Could you email the receipt to me please? Trainee: Of course John, could you please give me your email address so I can share it with you? SYM: Yes, my email address is test@test.com Trainee: Thanks John, so let me go ahead and share the receipt with you via email. Just a moment please. Trainee: So, the email was sent John, and you should be receiving it within the next 24 hours. SYM: Oh, I got the email, let me check. Okay, seems this is the one I was looking for, appreciate the help. Trainee: No problem John, it was a pleasure assisting you today. Is there anything else I could do for you today? SYM: No, that was all, thanks. Trainee: Alright, no problem. Before you disconnect, you’ll be transferred to a quick survey where you can evaluate the support I provided today. I’d really appreciate your feedback. SYM: I definitely will, thanks. Have a good day. Trainee: Thanks, you too John, thanks for calling Walmart Customer Relations, have a good day. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: Customer needed to locate a cash-purchased car seat stroller combo receipt (misplaced) and have the receipt emailed to them.
steps: Captured store details (store #1584, Rainbow 3615 Super Center) and confirmed the correct store.
Asked for purchase timeframe and approximate total to narrow the search (February, first two weeks; around $199, not exceeding $350).
Searched receipts based on the description and confirmed the item as Sonar Switch 6 in 1 Modular Stroller Travel System.
Verified the price on the receipt (car seat combo was $159).
Asked for and obtained the customer’s email address (test@test.com) to send the receipt.
Emailed the receipt to the customer and informed them it would arrive within 24 hours.
Customer confirmed receipt and expressed satisfaction with the document.
Closed the interaction and mentioned the post-call survey.

extraction.reason: Customer wanted to purchase a kayak online for in-store pickup but the site wouldn’t let them proceed; needed guidance to select pickup and complete the cart.
steps: Acknowledge issue and propose walking through the website steps to enable pickup.
Ask the customer to go to dickssportinggoods.com and locate the Shop Departments option.
Navigate to Outdoor > Kayaks and identify the Pelican Mustang 100 X the customer wants.
Explain that the color is a required product option and ensure the customer selects a color.
Instruct the customer to click the Pickup option to prompt for a ZIP code.
Have the customer enter their ZIP code and choose a nearby store, then click the X to close the store picker.

Confirm resolution and offer further assistance.

original_transcript: SYM: Being an AT&T work from home agent is not only rewarding, but also fun helping customers achieve more and realize more value from AT&T. In this simulation you have resolved a customers concern regarding their device, but then have an opportunity to transition to sales. There are 2 different transitions where we want to know what you would do. What would you say in response? Trainee: Thank you for calling AT&T. I hope we resolved your issue today. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, I just really needed to reset my data hotspot because it's my backup when the cable goes out. SYM: OK.... stop... How would you respond here? Trainee: Respond here. SYM: Thanks for the offer but I can't have my internet backup and my main internet service provider be from the same company, because I start working from home next month and need a reliable backup plan. SYM: OK.... stop... How would you respond here? Trainee: Respond here. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: The customer needed to reset their data hotspot as a backup internet connection for when their main cable service goes out.
steps: Agent greeted the customer and asked if there was anything else they could assist with after addressing the issue.
Customer stated they needed to reset their data hotspot because it is their backup when the cable goes out.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Northwestern Mutual, Underwriting Case Management, this is ________. How may I help you? SYM: Hi! This is Norm Weston calling from John Barrett's office. This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? Trainee: Hi Norm, may I start with a policy number to get started? SYM: This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? The policy number is T195129. Trainee: Thank you, Norm, I do have Marty's case pulled up here. You would like to talk about what will move this case to approval, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that is what I'm looking for. Trainee: Please give me a moment so I can review the details of the case and see what we can do to get this moving. SYM: Sounds good! Trainee: Thank you so much, I am all up to speed on this case. It looks like we are awaiting records from Dr. Smith's office and that a special authorization was sent to your office by the APS vendor to be reviewed. Do you have a copy of that completed form? SYM: No, I thought you sent it to the client and not just to me. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Let me take a moment to review the notes from our APS vendor to determine where the document was sent. SYM: Please do, I hope you sent it to the client. Trainee: It doesn't appear that this was sent directly to the client, instead it was sent to your office to facilitate that request. I can have that resent to you right away. SYM: Ok, that is fine. Do you really need these records though? It's been a long time. Trainee: It does look from the notes that the underwriter does require these notes in order to reach the final decision, however, I will put in a note requesting for a risk review and the underwriter will reach out with that information. In the meantime, I'll get the form over to you to reduce any further delay. SYM: That sounds fair. Thank you. Trainee: Of course. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all. Trainee: Awesome, well thank you so much for putting your trust in Northwestern Mutual. Have a great rest of your day. SYM: Thank you, you as well!

extraction.reason: The customer wanted to know why the case has been delayed and what the underwriter is waiting on, with a goal to move the case toward approval.
steps: Retrieved the policy number and opened the case to understand the current status.
Confirmed the customer’s goal to move the case toward approval.
Reviewed the case details to identify blockers, noting that records from Dr. Smith's office and a special authorization from the APS vendor were pending.
Checked whether the completed authorization form had been sent to the client; learned it had been sent to the office, not directly to the client, and offered to resend to the client.
Reviewed APS vendor notes to determine where the document was sent; confirmed it was sent to the office to facilitate the request and offered to resend to the client.
Informed the customer that the underwriter requires these notes to make a final decision and offered to place a note for a risk review, with the underwriter reaching out for the information.
Offered to send the required form to the client to reduce further delay.
Confirmed no additional needs from the customer and closed with appreciation.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Carnival, my name is [Agent Name]. May I have your name and booking number, please? SYM: Hi. My name is Mary, and my booking number is G H 6 0 J 8. Trainee: Great, Thank you. I will pull that up for you. Trainee: May I have your pin number please? SYM: 4 5 6 5. Trainee: Thank you for that. Trainee: I see that you and John are sailing on Carnival Horizon, December 6th, 2025, is that correct? SYM: Yes. Trainee: I see your email address is marytest@email.com, and your mobile number is 555 987-1234. You are currently not signed up for text alerts, would you like it to stay that way? SYM: Yes, I do not want text alerts. Trainee: And Mary, did you want to purchase the Carnival Vacation Protection today? SYM: No, thank you. Trainee: Ok, Mary. How can I help you today? SYM: I wanted to purchase the transfers. Trainee: No problem, Mary let me check a few things for you. SYM: Ok. Trainee: Thank you for your patience, Mary. Do you know what airport you’re flying into? SYM: Yes, the Miami International Airport. Trainee: Ok, great. If you fly into Miami it will be $22.99 one way, or $45.98 round trip, and I do have to tell you the recommended flight time for the pre cruise transfer is no later than 12PM, and the earliest flight for debarkation is no earlier than 12PM. Did you want to purchase for both guests? SYM: Yes . Trainee: Great, I will go ahead and add it for both guests. Trainee: Mary, may I confirm these changes? SYM: Yes, please add them. Trainee: Thank you, I’ve added the transfers for both guests. Do you have any other questions today, Mary? SYM: Yes, I have one more question, can you tell me about the ‘Behind the Fun’ tour ? Trainee: I’d be more than happy to tell you about that, Mary. One moment while I pull up the information. Trainee: Ok, Mary, you now have the option to book the ‘Behind the Fun’ tour before your cruise. It includes a limited edition ‘Behind the Fun’ baseball cap that marks you as an honorary team member, complimentary commemorative photos, some Carnival-branded goodies, and light snacks and pastries. Trainee: Since you'll be sailing on the Carnival Horizon, the tour starts at $130. It runs about 3 to 3¾ hours and gives you an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the ship. You’ll get to see the bridge, the engine control room, the main galley, staff dining areas, storerooms, the laundry, and more. It’s a rare chance to explore parts of the ship most guests never get to see. SYM: Awesome I will go on Carnival.com and book that. Trainee: That's great, each tour is limited to 16 people so booking in advance is recommended. Trainee: Mary, do you have any other questions for me today? SYM: No, that is all I had for you today. Trainee: It’s been my pleasure to assist you, Mary. Would you mind if I sent you a survey about my service today? SYM: Yes, you can do that. Trainee: Thank you for calling Carnival, Have a great day!

extraction.reason: To purchase pre-cruise transfers for two guests from the Miami airport.
steps: Pulled up and reviewed the customer’s booking (Mary, booking G H 60 J 8) and confirmed sailing on Carnival Horizon for December 6, 2025; verified PIN.
Confirmed contact details (email and mobile) and the customer’s preference to not receive text alerts; checked Vacation Protection status (declined).

Confirmed transfer request, discussed airport (Miami), pricing ($22.99 one-way or $45.98 round trip), and transfer timing guidelines (pre-cruise transfer no later than 12 PM; earliest debarkation flight no earlier than 12 PM) and that transfers would be for both guests.
Added transfers for both guests to the booking and confirmed the changes with the customer.
Provided information on the 'Behind the Fun' tour (price $130, approximately 3–3.75 hours, inclusions) and advised booking in advance; noted limited seating and suggested booking on Carnival.com.
Asked if there were any other questions and obtained permission to send a service survey at the end of the call.

original_transcript: SYM: Today we’re turning quoting chaos into quoting confidence—because pricing shouldn’t feel like rocket science! SYM: Here are a few tips for how to navigate throughout this Sym. Click the arrow when you’re ready to continue. SYM: The Quote Tool is a new tab available within a prospect or client record. SYM: Quote Parameter fields will auto populate with the available profile information of that record. SYM: Let’s go check it out in action in my favorite place, Salesforce! SYM: Great job getting a quote for Tim and his granddaughter. SYM: What if you have a caller on the line looking for a quote and they don’t have a Salesforce profile? SYM: There’s a quote tool for that situation too, using the DSC Quote Tool located at the bottom left of your Salesforce task bar. SYM: Let's practice! SYM: You’re really getting the hang of this quote tool! SYM: I wanted to bring your attention to a few more smart features of the Quote Tool. SYM: These features help make it easier for you to ensure you are providing accurate quotes on every call! SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Now that you’ve learned the Salesforce Quote Tool, go hit the phones and quote like a pro—fast, fearless, and fabulously accurate!

extraction.reason: Help learning how to use the Salesforce Quote Tool to create accurate quotes (including for callers without a Salesforce profile).
steps: Introduce the Quote Tool as a new tab in a prospect or client record and explain auto-population of Quote Parameter fields
Demonstrate using Salesforce to access and generate a quote (e.g., for Tim and his granddaughter)
Explain the DSC Quote Tool for callers who don’t have a Salesforce profile, located at the bottom left of the Salesforce task bar
Lead the user through practice and hands-on use of the tool to build familiarity
Highlight smart features of the Quote Tool to improve accuracy and speed
Review key learnings and encourage applying the tool on real calls

Well, thank you so much for giving us a call today. Let me help you to set up your new card information onto your account. Let me pull up your account first. May I know your name on the account, please? SYM: It's Lisa Turner, and I may need to change my address on my account as well. Trainee: Definitely, I can also help you with that. So, we can change the address first. Then afterwards we can update your payment information, too. SYM: Sure. Trainee: So, I do have now your account as 124578. original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation we will determine the learning style of each person. SYM: This is a screen navigational simulation. Follow the instructions provided throughout the simulation and complete the sym. SYM: This is the Hotspot. You would need to click on it to type in the answer or you would need to click on it to move to the next step. After typing in the details, you would need to click the 'enter' key to move forward. SYM: Concentrate on each slide detail to WIN the quiz at the end. SYM: There are several types of learning, categorized based on theories, approaches, and settings. Here’s an overview SYM: Visual learners understand best through pictures, charts, and diagrams. They prefer shapes and patterns over words or speech. Teachers can help by using tools like graphic organizers to explain ideas clearly. SYM: Auditory learners learn best by hearing and speaking. They enjoy lectures, group discussions, and talking through ideas. They often figure things out by speaking first, rather than planning what to say. SYM: Reading & writing learners understand best through words. They enjoy reading and do well with written tasks like stories or reports. They prefer learning through text, such as reading books or writing notes. Teachers can help by asking them to explain diagrams or charts in writing, which they can review later to remember the information. SYM: Kinesthetic learners learn best by doing. They like hands-on activities, real-life examples, and practicing skills through physical actions. Teachers can help by giving them practical tasks, like recreating experiments or working through examples to understand new ideas. SYM: Now let’s determine your learning style through a quick evaluation. SYM: Tip: [Now you’ve to speak the correct option showing on the screen based on your preferences and click “Next” to proceed.] SYM: What was the arrow color in the previous slide? I would Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: A website has a video showing how to make a special graph or chart. A person is speaking, some lists and words describing what to do, and some diagrams. I would learn most from Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to find out more about a tour that I am going on. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When choosing a career or area of study, these are important for me: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When I am learning I Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: You learning like a pro!!! I want to learn how to play a new board game or card game. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to learn to do something new on a computer. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I have finished a competition or test and would like feedback: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to learn how to take better photos. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When learning from the Internet I like: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: Now select which category you think suits you best! SYM: Write down in the text box given. SYM: Click on ‘FINISH’. SYM: Congratulations!!! Nows've completed the assessment. Your trainer will tell you the result. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

steps: Explain the concept and categories of learning styles (visual, auditory, reading/writing, kinesthetic).

original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation, you will help a customer identify whether a procedure is covered by their health insurance. SYM: STEP 1 - Opening. SYM: [Phone rings] Trainee: Thank you for calling ABC Health Insurance. My name is [YOUR NAME]. How may I assist you today? SYM: Hi, my name is Ash. I wanted to inquire if a specific medical procedure is covered by my health insurance. Trainee: Of course, Ash. I'm here to help. May I have your first and last name? SYM: Ash Harris. Trainee: I appreciate it. Can you please provide me with your policy number so that I can access your account? SYM: Sure, my policy number is A B C 1 2 3 4 5 6. SYM: STEP 2 - Gather Information. Trainee: Thank you, Ash. Let me pull up your policy information. While I do that, could you please provide me with the details of the medical procedure you're inquiring about? SYM: I'm considering getting a knee surgery called arthroscopic meniscectomy. I wanted to know if it's covered under my policy. Trainee: I understand. Let me check the specifics of your coverage. Just give me a moment, please. Trainee: Thank you for waiting, Ash. I have reviewed your policy, and I can confirm that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered under your health insurance plan. However, it's important to note that coverage can vary based on factors such as medical necessity, network providers, and any applicable deductibles or co-payments. SYM: That's great to hear! Could you please provide me with some additional information? For instance, do I need a referral from my primary care physician before scheduling the surgery? Trainee: That's an excellent question, Ash. According to your policy, you do not require a referral from your primary care physician for this specific procedure. However, it's always a good idea to consult with your doctor or surgeon to ensure that the surgery is appropriate for your specific medical condition. SYM: I see. Thank you for clarifying that. Now, I'm also curious about the coverage limits and any out-of-pocket expenses I may incur. Trainee: Certainly, Ash. Let me go over that with you. Your policy has a coverage limit for surgical procedures, and I can see that it includes coverage for this specific surgery. As for out-of-pocket expenses, it's important to review your policy documents or contact our claims department to determine any deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance that may apply. SYM: I'll make sure to review my policy documents. Lastly, could you provide me with a list of in-network surgeons or facilities that perform this procedure? Trainee: Absolutely, Ash. I can assist you with that. Please bear with me while I access the network provider information. SYM: No worries. Trainee: Thank you for your patience, Ash. I have compiled a list of in-network surgeons and facilities that perform arthroscopic meniscectomy in your area. I will email you the list to the email address we have on file. Additionally, you can also visit our website or contact our customer service line to obtain this information. SYM: That's perfect. Thank you so much for your help. You've been very informative. SYM: STEP 3 - Closing. Trainee: You're welcome. Can you confirm your email address for me? SYM: That would be Ash@email.com Trainee: Thank you, Ash. I'm glad I could assist you. If you have any further questions or need any additional information, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you make the most of your health insurance coverage. SYM: I appreciate that. Thanks again for your assistance. Trainee: It's my pleasure, Ash. Take care, and have a great day! SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: To determine whether arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered by Ash Harris's health insurance policy and to understand related details (referral requirement, costs, and in-network providers).
steps: Opening: greet the customer, introduce self, and collect identifying information including policy number.
Access policy: pull up the customer's policy information while gathering details about the requested procedure.
Check coverage: confirm that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered under the policy and describe factors that might affect coverage (medical necessity, network providers, deductibles, co-pays).
Clarify referrals: determine whether a referral from a primary care physician is required for this procedure (in this case, no referral needed).
Explain costs: outline potential out-of-pocket expenses and advise reviewing policy documents or contacting claims for deductibles, co-pays, or coinsurance.
Provide in-network options: compile and share a list of in-network surgeons/facilities that perform the procedure and offer to email it or direct the customer to the website/phone.
Close: confirm contact details (email), invite further questions, and thank the customer.

original_transcript: SYM: Click on the arrow at the side of Interaction Record and click on Internal Commitment SYM: This will open a new style screen.
