In this case the 9th July. SYM: If the Responsible group field has not auto populated click on the two boxes. SYM: Type in the code csc_tsp in the Search term field. SYM: Click Search SYM: Double click on the relevant line. SYM: Click into two squares on Interaction Centre Agent field SYM: Add your last name (agent) into the Last name field - in this case 'Hall' SYM: Add your first name (agent) into the First name field - in this case 'Dawn' SYM: Click Search and double click on your own CPT - in this case CPT-HAD SYM: Under Notes in the box that say’s ‘write note…’ please add a brief note of the conversation and what you have advised the customer. SYM: Once notes are added click Create Internal Commitment. SYM: You are now on the Internal Commitment page. This page is where you select the team the commitment goes too and the instructions that are needed. SYM: Leave the Employee Responsible field blank and click on the 2 boxes at the side of Responsible group SYM: In the Search term box type in the relevant code from the Commitments matrix in this case cbs_dasp SYM: Click Search SYM: Double click on the relevant team you are sending the commitment to. original_transcript: SYM: Welcome to SymTrain! I’m Coach Sym and I’m here to help you get familiar with using the DSC training resource, SymTrain. SYM: Let’s start by reviewing some tips for how to navigate throughout a Sym. SYM: When you see a box outlined in blue, that is something in the sym you need to click in order to continue. SYM: A green box indicates a text field. You will need to type a response in the box. Use your mouse to click inside the box, type the required text, then press enter on your keyboard while still in the text box to submit your response. SYM: Let’s practice! Type your favorite color in the box that appears. SYM: Thanks for sharing! SYM: The final interaction portion you will encounter in syms is speaking. SYM: If a sym requires a verbal response, a microphone will appear. Say your answer out loud, then click the next button to continue. SYM: Let’s practice! When the microphone icon appears, read the dialogue that appears in the bottom of your screen, then click next. Trainee: Hello, my name is (your first name). SYM: Great job! SYM: Let’s continue with how to navigate SymTrain. SYM: Your SymTrain Home page will show your Overall Stats on the syms you have completed. SYM: You are also able to make Accessibility Adjustments. SYM: Here are some of the options available. After this sym, feel free to check out how the different settings work and toggle on any settings that are beneficial to you. SYM: SymTrain also has a built in Support feature if you need help at any time. SYM: You have the option to message SymTrain for support, provide feedback, or use the SymTrain AI_Help for self-troubleshooting. SYM: Since you are taking this sym, you have obviously learned how to launch a sym – way to go! SYM: However, you might not have realized there is more than one way to launch a sym. SYM: The first is click the play icon next to any of the syms shown on your Home page. SYM: The second is from your My Exercises tab, let’s head there now. SYM: Here is where you will find all syms that have been assigned to you as well as your progress. SYM: As you continue your journey in the DSC, you may have more than 10 rows of assignments and will need to expand your rows per page or view the other pages to find assignments. SYM: If you see a stacked icon, that indicates that is a sym module, which means it contains more than one sym. Click the icon to expand and see the included syms. SYM: On the right, you can see what syms you have already completed in that module. SYM: To launch a sym from your exercises, you can click on the play icon on the left of the sym or module. SYM: Or you can click on an individual sym from the module list to launch that sym. Let’s practice that. SYM: As you already saw, you can select if you would like to proceed with completing a Practice or Test version of the sym. SYM: You can also select a different sym to launch from the module list by clicking the play icon on the sym tile. SYM: Some syms, like the one you are taking right now, require verbal responses. It is important to make sure the correct microphone setting is selected so SymTrain can hear you and record your response. SYM: Before starting your first sym of the day, you should check your hardware. SYM: Using your company provided headset is the best practice to ensure that SymTrain can pick up your voice clearly. To use the headset while in a sym, make sure it is plugged into your laptop and not your phone. SYM: While you can select your laptop’s built in microphone as an option, depending on your desk setup that microphone might be too far away to pick up your voice clearly. SYM: Let’s practice what this would look like. SYM: For the purposes of this sym, we will give you a prompt to speak into the microphone. SYM: When you a ready, click Start Recording for a prompt to appear at the bottom of the screen. SYM: Say the prompt out loud, then click the Next icon that appears to continue. Trainee: Mic check. Test one, two, three. SYM: Great job! After recording, there will be a playback button that will allow you to hear how you sound to ensure quality recording throughout any sym that day. SYM: That was just a simulated practice. Be sure to check this feature out for real before your next sym. SYM: The final area to explore is the Playback. We will review that next sym. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Fantastic job completing your first sym! Let’s stay on track and head over to the next one where we learn how to view your sym playback.

extraction.reason: The trainee needs help learning how to use SymTrain (navigation, launching syms, handling text and verbal responses, and hardware setup).
steps: Explain that blue boxes are clickable items to continue and green boxes are text fields to type into
Demonstrate typing a response (practice by entering a favorite color) and submitting
Explain verbal responses: if a mic is required, a microphone will appear and you should speak then click next
Show how to navigate to the SymTrain Home page to view Overall Stats and access accessibility adjustments
Introduce the built-in Support features (message support, provide feedback, or use AI_Help for self-troubleshooting)
Explain there are multiple ways to launch a sym: click the play icon on the Home page or use the My Exercises tab
Describe the My Exercises tab: contains assigned syms, progress, and how to expand rows or view additional pages
Explain that a stacked icon indicates a sym module and clicking it expands to show included syms
Show how to launch a sym from a module either by clicking the play icon on the tile or by selecting the individual sym
Explain choosing between Practice or Test versions and selecting a different sym from the module list
Note that some syms require verbal responses and emphasize selecting the correct microphone settings
Provide hardware guidance: use a company headset plugged into the laptop for clear voice pickup and avoid using the phone microphone
Demonstrate the recording workflow: click Start Recording, speak the prompt, then use Next to continue and use playback to review
Conclude with a recap and encourage reviewing key learnings by clicking the lightbulb to proceed

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Barnes and Noble. My name is (Your Name). How can I help you? SYM: Hello. My name is Anita Napp. I just called and the nice man told me that he would send me a new copy of my book because it wasn't delivered. As soon as we hung up, my mail was delivered. The book was in today's mail! Can you cancel the new order that was just placed? Trainee: No problem, Anita. I would be happy to see if we can cancel the new order for you. Can I have your Order Number, please? SYM: Sure, my order number is 6123456789. Trainee: Thank you. Can I please have you verify your email address? SYM: Sure. My email address is anita napp at gmail.com. Trainee: Thank you. What is the shipping address on the order? SYM: My address is 1 2 3 Main Street. That's in Anytown, Ohio 4 3 5 5 5. Trainee: Thank you. One moment while I research to see if I can cancel the order. Trainee: Your order is in a status that I can't make any changes, but I can send a cancel request to the warehouse. I can't promise that it will be cancelled, but we will update you within 24 hours whether we can cancel the order or not. Would you like me to proceed with canceling the order? SYM: Yes, I don't need two copies of the same book. Trainee: No problem. One moment while I send the request. Trainee: Thank you for your patience. I've sent the request to cancel your order. You'll receive an email within 24 hours to let you know if we can cancel the order or not. You can return it if we can't get it canceled. SYM: Ok, thanks. I appreciate it. Trainee: You're welcome. Is there anything else I can assist you with today? SYM: No, that's it. Thanks. Trainee: Thank you for calling Barnes and Noble. Have a great day.

extraction.reason: Customer asked to cancel the new order for a replacement book that had just been placed because the original book arrived in the mail.
steps: Greeted the customer and confirmed the purpose: to cancel the new order.
Asked for and recorded the order number: 6123456789.
Verified account details: email address anita napp at gmail.com and shipping address 1 2 3 Main Street, Anytown, Ohio 4 3 5 5 5.
Checked the order status and explained that direct changes weren't possible, but a cancel request could be sent to the warehouse with no guaranteed outcome.
Obtained the customer's confirmation to proceed with submitting the cancel request.
Submitted the cancel request to the warehouse and informed the customer they would receive an email within 24 hours with the result; advised they could return the item if cancellation isn't possible.

original_transcript: SYM: You have already opened the call and verified customer details. In this simulation, you will gather information and resolve the customer's concern. SYM: STEP 2 - Gather Information. Trainee: Thank you, Ash. Let me pull up your policy information. While I do that, could you please provide me with the details of the medical procedure you're inquiring about? SYM: I'm considering getting a knee surgery called arthroscopic meniscectomy. I wanted to know if it's covered under my policy. Trainee: I understand. Let me check the specifics of your coverage. Just give me a moment, please. Trainee: Thank you for waiting, Ash. I have reviewed your policy, and I can confirm that arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered under your health insurance plan. However, it's important to note that coverage can vary based on factors such as medical necessity, network providers, and any applicable deductibles or co-payments. SYM: That's great to hear! Could you please provide me with some additional information? For instance, do I need a referral from my primary care physician before scheduling the surgery? Trainee: That's an excellent question, Ash. According to your policy, you do not require a referral from your primary care physician for this specific procedure. However, it's always a good idea to consult with your doctor or surgeon to ensure that the surgery is appropriate for your specific medical condition. SYM: I see. Thank you for clarifying that. Now, I'm also curious about the coverage limits and any out-of-pocket expenses I may incur. Trainee: Certainly, Ash. Let me go over that with you. Your policy has a coverage limit for surgical procedures, and I can see that it includes coverage for this specific surgery. As for out-of-pocket expenses, it's important to review your policy documents or contact our claims department to determine any deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance that may apply. SYM: I'll make sure to review my policy documents. Lastly, could you provide me with a list of in-network surgeons or facilities that perform this procedure? Trainee: Absolutely, Ash. I can assist you with that. Please bear with me while I access the network provider information. SYM: No worries. Trainee: Thank you for your patience, Ash. I have compiled a list of in-network surgeons and facilities that perform arthroscopic meniscectomy in your area. I will email you the list to the email address we have on file. Additionally, you can also visit our website or contact our customer service line to obtain this information. SYM: That's perfect. Thank you so much for your help. You've been very informative. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: Customer sought to determine if arthroscopic meniscectomy is covered by their health policy, including questions about referrals, costs, and in-network providers.
steps: Gathered policy and procedure details from the customer to assess coverage (arthroscopic meniscectomy).
Checked the policy to confirm coverage for the procedure and explained factors that can affect coverage (medical necessity, network, deductibles, co-payments).
Verified whether a referral from a primary care physician is required for this procedure and informed the customer that no referral is needed.
Discussed potential coverage limits and out-of-pocket costs, advising the customer to review policy documents or contact claims for specifics (deductibles, co-payments, coinsurance).
Retrieved in-network provider information and prepared a list of surgeons/facilities; planned to email the list to the customer and noted alternative access via the website or customer service line.

original_transcript: SYM: It’s closing time for this module. SYM: So, let’s recap all your learnings, move it to the phones. SYM: I hope you have learned something new. SYM: Throughout the call, you work hard to gain trust, establish credibility, discover needs, and utilize that information to find the right product for that caller’s needs. SYM: However, you can’t get the sale if you don’t ask! That’s the importance of closing. SYM: We should be asking for the sale immediately after providing the price. SYM: This is why a best practice during the discover process is to ask the budget question last, because it is a natural transition to price. SYM: By asking the budget question last, you are in a better position to successfully close because you have all your information you need to know to offer the right product based on the customers needs. SYM: There are multiple closing techniques you can use. SYM: Find the one that works best for your personality and call style. SYM: You don’t have to use the same one every time, don’t be afraid to step outside your comfort zone and try something new! SYM: Hearing no can and will happen to everyone in a sales role. SYM: There is not a closing technique that guarantees everyone will say yes. SYM: Remember to catch it, catch it, change it when it comes to hearing no on calls. SYM: You will hear more no’s than yes’s and that’s okay. SYM: So don’t be afraid to go for no - that means you at least asked for the sale! SYM: It’s officially closing time, open all the queues and let you out into those calls!

extraction.reason: Training on closing sales calls: learn when and how to ask for the sale, budget handling, and handling objections.
steps: Close the module and transition to live calls
Emphasize building trust, credibility, and discovering needs on the call
Use information gathered to identify the right product for the caller
Provide price information and then ask for the sale
Position the budget question last to create a natural transition to price
Choose a closing technique that fits your personality and call style
Don’t rely on a single technique; be willing to try new methods
Prepare for and normalize hearing 'no' on calls
Understand there is no closing technique that guarantees a sale
Use the 'catch it, catch it, change it' approach to responding to a no
Accept that you will hear more no's than yes's and that’s okay
Go for no: asking for the sale at least ensures you attempted to close
End the module and prepare to handle live calls

original_transcript: SYM: Hello! If you are starting this sym, that means you chose the Urgency Close as the technique you would like to try on your calls. ​ If you wanted to try a different closing technique, now is the time to exit this sym and head to the one you wanted to practice.​ ​ SYM: Here are a few tips for how to navigate throughout this Sym. Click the arrow when you’re ready to continue.​ SYM: As reviewed earlier, the Urgency Close technique creates a sense of immediacy and potential loss if the customer does not purchase today.​ SYM: Here’s an example of how an urgency close might sound.​ SYM: When you get this policy today, you’re locking in the rate. Which means you’re getting the best rate from us before you get any older. ​ SYM: Remember, we are going to ask for the sale immediately after providing the price.​ This is why a best practice during the discover process is to ask the budget question last to put yourself in a better position to successfully close because you have all your information you need to know to offer the right product based on the customers needs.​ ​ SYM: Here are some more examples of an Urgency Close. ​ SYM: PRICE, and when you get this policy today, you’re locking in the rate. Which means you’re getting the best rate from us before you get any older. ​ SYM: PRICE, and if you wait until you get older, you’re just going to have to pay more. You’ll want to do this today so you can lock in this rate. ​ SYM: PRICE. With your birthday coming up next month, let’s get this taken care of today so you can lock in this rate before you get older!​ SYM: PRICE. Anything can happen tomorrow, so let’s make sure you and your family are prepared today by getting this policy in place.​ SYM: Notice that something they have in common is making the sale today.​ SYM: These examples are in other people’s words, take a moment to write down how you would word your empathy close.​ SYM: You’ve completed the discovery process with Sonya and have determined that an $8,000 UCSL policy will best meet her needs.​ SYM: Take a moment to review the information and write down an Urgency Close you could use for Sonya.​ Remember, you should ask for the sale immediately after providing the price.​ SYM: Click the “I’m Ready!” icon when you are ready to practice your option close.​ Trainee: ... SYM: Great job practicing your Urgency Close. SYM: You don’t want to miss out on an opportunity to close a sale, so go use the urgency close on your next call - you got this!​

extraction.reason: The customer (Sonya) wanted to proceed with purchasing an insurance policy, specifically an $8,000 UCSL policy that would meet her needs.
steps: Identify that the trainee has chosen the Urgency Close technique and explain how to proceed or exit to try a different closing technique if desired.
Explain the purpose of the Urgency Close: to create immediacy and the potential loss if the customer does not purchase today.
Provide a sample Urgency Close script so the trainee can hear how the language should flow when presenting the price and the close.
Emphasize best practice: ask the budget question last during the discovery so you have enough information to tailor the offer based on needs.
Offer additional Urgency Close examples (phrases about locking in the rate, age-related pricing, or immediate action to prepare for the future).
Highlight that the close should occur immediately after providing the price to secure the sale.
Reference the discovery outcome: Sonya’s needs indicate an $8,000 UCSL policy as the best fit.
Ask the trainee to review the information and draft a personalized Urgency Close for Sonya.
Instruct the trainee to click 'I’m Ready!' to practice the option close and proceed with the exercise.
Provide encouragement and close with positive reinforcement to practice the Urgency Close on the next call.

original_transcript: SYM: Welcome back! Congratulations on completing your first sym a moment ago. Now let’s see how you did. SYM: Before we get started, I want to draw your attention to the sym time length on the opening screen of each sym. SYM: This lets you know on average how long it should take to complete the sym. SYM: Take a moment to look for the “Time Elapsed” located at the top of this sym. SYM: As you work through syms, be sure to keep an eye on your pace so you can finish within the allotted time for the assignment. SYM: Let’s proceed full steam ahead! SYM: Reminder, here are some best practices for navigating throughout a sym. Click the arrow when you are ready to continue. SYM: After completing a sym, you will be directed to a screen that looks like this. SYM: From here you can already see your Completion Time, Keyword Score, and Click Score. SYM: To view more details on your sym score, click View Playback. SYM: This playback view provides more insight on your performance. SYM: You can see if you completed the sym in Practice or Test Mode, the day and time completed, and you can even click re-attempt and do it again from here. SYM: Here is that completion time again. SYM: Completion time is important because if it is taking you longer to navigate the conversation and screens, it can be an indication that you just need to practice the sym more to learn the process better. SYM: Let’s break down the other stats on the screen, starting with Keyword Score. SYM: Keywords are structure words in the conversation that are good word choices or can even be compliance words that must be said. If the sym has no agent lines, you will not have a keyword score. SYM: The DSC is not a scripted environment. The key words chosen throughout the syms will be ones that everyone should say. SYM: For example, everyone should state “Mutual of Omaha” in your call introduction. SYM: The first number is your keyword score, and the second is the possible score. SYM: In that last sym, I got 3 out of 4 keywords correct. SYM: To see which one I missed, I can scroll down to find it in the playback. SYM: Words highlighted green indicate you got the keyword correct, while red indicates it was missed. SYM: Here I can see that I missed the first word, hello. SYM: You can click the Trainee Response to jump to that part of the recording, then click Play to listen. SYM: After listening to my playback, I could here that I said hello, but the microphone didn’t start picking up right away so the greeting was cut off. SYM: Technology is not perfect. There could also be times where it thought you said a different word. For example, application and occupation can sound similar to a computer. SYM: That is why the training team and your supervisors review playback on lower scoring syms. SYM: This allows them to see if it was a system error or a coaching opportunity. SYM: Scroll back to the top to look at the rest of the sym score. SYM: Let’s review Click Score next. SYM: Click Score is scoring where on the visual components of the sym you navigated and clicked through during the process. Click score will only be in visual syms. SYM: The first number is your click score, and the second is the possible score. SYM: In that last sym, I got 19 out of 19 clicks correct. Way to go me! That is a good indicator that I understand the process in the sym. SYM: Confidence, Concentration and Energy are your sentiment scores. SYM: These scores are calculated by the level of intent you deliver the script line in the areas of confidence, concentration and energy. SYM: These are not calculated on your voice or tone, but on how confident your level of intent is, your focus or concentration level, and your pace or energy level. SYM: The sentiment score is calculated for the entire sym, not one part or another. SYM: My Energy score was Medium. I can click Insights to view more. SYM: This is where I can find insight on how to improve that score if I were to take it again, or helpful advice for future syms. SYM: Next let’s look at the Sym Accuracy Score. SYM: This measures how well your response matched the intent of what the customer was asking in the customer script line. SYM: SymTrain is still working on improvements to the Sym Accuracy score, and this is being monitored by the training team at the moment. SYM: The final stat to look at is the Sym Score. SYM: This will equal a combined score of the different scoring options for that sym. If this is a beginner sym your score should be in the 80% range. SYM: Again, technology is not perfect. That is why the training team and supervisors will take a look at those lower scores to see if it was a system error or a coaching opportunity for improvement. SYM: Now that we’ve reviewed how to look at detailed playback after completing a sym, let’s head to the Playback page. SYM: The Playback page provides an overview of your sym performance for all your completed syms. SYM: To view the detailed playback for any sym, simply click the Actions icon. SYM: This concludes the simulation. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Fantastic job completing SymTrain 1 0 1! You are ready to continue your learning journey and start taking syms! Bon voyage!

original_transcript: SYM: Welcome to SymTrain! I’m Coach Sym and I’m here to help you get familiar with using the DSC training resource, SymTrain. SYM: Let’s start by reviewing some tips for how to navigate throughout a Sym. SYM: When you see a box outlined in blue, that is something in the sym you need to click in order to continue. SYM: A green box indicates a text field. You will need to type a response in the box. Use your mouse to click inside the box, type the required text, then press enter on your keyboard while still in the text box to submit your response. SYM: Let’s practice! Type your favorite color in the box that appears. SYM: Thanks for sharing! SYM: The final interaction portion you will encounter in syms is speaking. SYM: If a sym requires a verbal response, a microphone will appear. Say your answer out loud, then click the next button to continue. SYM: Let’s practice! When the microphone icon appears, read the dialogue that appears in the bottom of your screen, then click next. Trainee: Hello, my name is (your first name). SYM: Great job! SYM: Let’s continue with how to navigate SymTrain. SYM: Your SymTrain Home page will show your Overall Stats on the syms you have completed. SYM: You are also able to make Accessibility Adjustments. SYM: Here are some of the options available. After this sym, feel free to check out how the different settings work and toggle on any settings that are beneficial to you. SYM: SymTrain also has a built in Support feature if you need help at any time. SYM: You have the option to message SymTrain for support, provide feedback, or use the SymTrain AI_Help for self-troubleshooting. SYM: Since you are taking this sym, you have obviously learned how to launch a sym – way to go! SYM: However, you might not have realized there is more than one way to launch a sym. SYM: The first is click the play icon next to any of the syms shown on your Home page. SYM: The second is from your My Exercises tab, let’s head there now. SYM: Here is where you will find all syms that have been assigned to you as well as your progress. SYM: As you continue your journey in the DSC, you may have more than 10 rows of assignments and will need to expand your rows per page or view the other pages to find assignments. SYM: If you see a stacked icon, that indicates that is a sym module, which means it contains more than one sym. Click the icon to expand and see the included syms. SYM: On the right, you can see what syms you have already completed in that module. SYM: To launch a sym from your exercises, you can click on the play icon on the left of the sym or module. SYM: Or you can click on an individual sym from the module list to launch that sym. Let’s practice that. SYM: As you already saw, you can select if you would like to proceed with completing a Practice or Test version of the sym. SYM: You can also select a different sym to launch from the module list by clicking the play icon on the sym tile. SYM: Some syms, like the one you are taking right now, require verbal responses. It is important to make sure the correct microphone setting is selected so SymTrain can hear you and record your response. SYM: Before starting your first sym of the day, you should check your hardware. SYM: Using your company provided headset is the best practice to ensure that SymTrain can pick up your voice clearly. To use the headset while in a sym, make sure it is plugged into your laptop and not your phone. SYM: While you can select your laptop’s built in microphone as an option, depending on your desk setup that microphone might be too far away to pick up your voice clearly. SYM: Let’s practice what this would look like. SYM: For the purposes of this sym, we will give you a prompt to speak into the microphone. SYM: When you a ready, click Start Recording for a prompt to appear at the bottom of the screen. SYM: Say the prompt out loud, then click the Next icon that appears to continue. Trainee: Mic check. Test one, two, three. SYM: Great job! After recording, there will be a playback button that will allow you to hear how you sound to ensure quality recording throughout any sym that day. SYM: That was just a simulated practice. Be sure to check this feature out for real before your next sym. SYM: The final area to explore is the Playback. We will review that next sym. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Fantastic job completing your first sym! Let’s stay on track and head over to the next one where we learn how to view your sym playback.

steps: Introduced SymTrain and the goal of helping the user get familiar with the resource.

Provided hardware tips to avoid using the phone microphone and to place the mic within range.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Northwestern Mutual, Underwriting Case Management, this is ________. How may I help you? SYM: Hi! This is Norm Weston calling from John Barrett's office. This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? Trainee: Hi Norm, may I start with a policy number to get started? SYM: This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? The policy number is T195129. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Give me one moment to pull up the case. Trainee: Thank you, Norm, I do have Marty's case pulled up here. You would like to talk about what will move this case to approval, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that is what I'm looking for. Trainee: Please give me a moment so I can review the details of the case and see what we can do to get this moving. SYM: Sounds good! Trainee: Thank you so much, I am all up to speed on this case. It looks like we are awaiting records from Dr. Smith's office and that a special authorization was sent to your office by the APS vendor to be reviewed. Do you have a copy of that completed form? SYM: No, I thought you sent it to the client and not just to me. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Let me take a moment to review the notes from our APS vendor to determine where the document was sent. SYM: Please do, I hope you sent it to the client. Trainee: It doesn't appear that this was sent directly to the client, instead it was sent to your office to facilitate that request. I can have that resent to you right away. SYM: Ok, that is fine. Do you really need these records though? It's been a long time. Trainee: It does look from the notes that the underwriter does require these notes in order to reach the final decision, however, I will put in a note requesting for a risk review and the underwriter will reach out with that information. In the meantime, I'll get the form over to you to reduce any further delay. SYM: That sounds fair. Thank you. Trainee: Of course. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all. Trainee: Awesome, well thank you so much for putting your trust in Northwestern Mutual. Have a great rest of your day. SYM: Thank you, you as well!

Offer to resend the APS form to reduce delay.
Acknowledge that the underwriter requires these notes to reach a final decision and plan to place a risk review note.
Submit a note requesting a risk review and inform the caller that the underwriter will reach out with additional information.

Close by asking if there is anything else you can assist with and thank the caller.

original_transcript: SYM: Today we’re turning quoting chaos into quoting confidence—because pricing shouldn’t feel like rocket science! SYM: Here are a few tips for how to navigate throughout this Sym. Click the arrow when you’re ready to continue. SYM: The Quote Tool is a new tab available within a prospect or client record. SYM: Quote Parameter fields will auto populate with the available profile information of that record. SYM: Let’s go check it out in action in my favorite place, Salesforce! SYM: Great job getting a quote for Tim and his granddaughter. SYM: What if you have a caller on the line looking for a quote and they don’t have a Salesforce profile? SYM: There’s a quote tool for that situation too, using the DSC Quote Tool located at the bottom left of your Salesforce task bar. SYM: Let's practice! SYM: You’re really getting the hang of this quote tool! SYM: I wanted to bring your attention to a few more smart features of the Quote Tool. SYM: These features help make it easier for you to ensure you are providing accurate quotes on every call! SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Now that you’ve learned the Salesforce Quote Tool, go hit the phones and quote like a pro—fast, fearless, and fabulously accurate!

extraction.reason: Customer needed help with using the Salesforce Quote Tool to generate quotes.
steps: Introduce the Salesforce Quote Tool and its purpose (to turn quoting chaos into confidence).
Explain that Quote Parameter fields auto-populate from the record's profile information.
Demonstrate how to access and use the Quote Tool within Salesforce.
Highlight the DSC Quote Tool for callers without a Salesforce profile, located at the bottom left of the Salesforce task bar.
Provide a practice run to help the user become proficient with the tool.
Point out additional smart features of the Quote Tool to ensure accurate quotes.
Ask the user to review the key learnings from the session.
Encourage applying the Salesforce Quote Tool on calls to quote quickly and accurately.

original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation we will determine the learning style of each person. SYM: This is a screen navigational simulation. Follow the instructions provided throughout the simulation and complete the sym. SYM: This is the Hotspot. You would need to click on it to type in the answer or you would need to click on it to move to the next step. After typing in the details, you would need to click the 'enter' key to move forward. SYM: Concentrate on each slide detail to WIN the quiz at the end. SYM: There are several types of learning, categorized based on theories, approaches, and settings. Here’s an overview SYM: Visual learners understand best through pictures, charts, and diagrams. They prefer shapes and patterns over words or speech. Teachers can help by using tools like graphic organizers to explain ideas clearly. SYM: Auditory learners learn best by hearing and speaking. They enjoy lectures, group discussions, and talking through ideas. They often figure things out by speaking first, rather than planning what to say. SYM: Reading & writing learners understand best through words. They enjoy reading and do well with written tasks like stories or reports. They prefer learning through text, such as reading books or writing notes. Teachers can help by asking them to explain diagrams or charts in writing, which they can review later to remember the information. SYM: Kinesthetic learners learn best by doing. They like hands-on activities, real-life examples, and practicing skills through physical actions. Teachers can help by giving them practical tasks, like recreating experiments or working through examples to understand new ideas. SYM: Now let’s determine your learning style through a quick evaluation. SYM: Tip: [Now you’ve to speak the correct option showing on the screen based on your preferences and click “Next” to proceed.] SYM: What was the arrow color in the previous slide? SYM: What was the mistake in the previous slide’s sentence? SYM: Let's start!!! I need to find the way to a shop that a friend has recommended. I would Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: A website has a video showing how to make a special graph or chart. A person is speaking, some lists and words describing what to do, and some diagrams. I would learn most from Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to find out more about a tour that I am going on. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When choosing a career or area of study, these are important for me: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When I am learning I Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: You learning like a pro!!! I want to learn how to play a new board game or card game. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to learn to do something new on a computer. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I have finished a competition or test and would like feedback: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: I want to learn how to take better photos. I would: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: When learning from the Internet I like: Trainee: Options: A, B, C, D SYM: Now select which category you think suits you best! SYM: Write down in the text box given. SYM: Click on ‘FINISH’. SYM: Congratulations!!! Nows've completed the assessment. Your trainer will tell you the result. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: To determine the user’s learning style through a quick interactive assessment within a training simulation.
steps: Explain the purpose of the simulation and how to navigate (hotspot clicks, typing input, and pressing enter to proceed).
Provide an overview of the four learning styles (visual, auditory, reading/writing, kinesthetic) with definitions and teaching tips.
Instruct the user to start a quick evaluation and to respond by selecting the option shown on screen and clicking Next.
Framing questions to engage the user (e.g., asking about the arrow color and a previous sentence’s mistake) to orient attention.
Present scenario-based prompts where the user selects A, B, C, or D to indicate their preferred learning approach for different situations.
Ask the user to choose the category that best suits them and to write it in a text box.
Instruct the user to click FINISH to complete the assessment.
Conclude by confirming completion and noting that the trainer will provide the results.

original_transcript: SYM: In this simulation, you will learn how to create an F N O L claim for a car insurance company. SYM: STEP 1 - Opening. SYM: [Phone rings] Trainee: Thank you for calling ABC Insurance. My name is [YOUR NAME]. How may I assist you today? SYM: Hi. I need to file a car insurance claim for an accident I was just involved in. SYM: STEP 2 - Gather Information. Trainee: I'm sorry to hear about the accident. Let's start by making sure we have all the necessary information. May I have your first and last name? SYM: Pat Davis. Trainee: Thank you, Can you please provide me with your policy number? SYM: Yes, it's A B C 1 2 3 4 5 6. Trainee: Thank you, Pat. I see your policy here. Now, could you please provide me with the date and time of the accident? SYM: The accident occurred today, May 17th, 2023, at around 3:30 p.m. Trainee: Got it. And can you briefly describe what happened during the accident? SYM: I was driving on Main Street when another car ran a red light and crashed into the driver's side of my vehicle. It was a T-bone collision. Trainee: I'm sorry to hear that. Is everyone involved in the accident safe and is anyone injured? SYM: Fortunately, no one was seriously injured, but both cars sustained significant damage. Trainee: I'm glad to hear that no one was hurt. Safety is our top priority. Now, could you please provide me with the contact and insurance information of the other party involved in the accident? SYM: The other driver's name is Sarah Johnson, and her phone number is (555) 123 - 4567. I also have her insurance information. Her insurance company is XYZ Insurance, and her policy number is D E F 9 8 7 6 5 4. Trainee: Thank you for providing that information, Pat. Now, I need to gather some details about your vehicle. Can you please provide me with the make, model, and year of your car? SYM: Sure. I drive a 2018 Honda Accord. Trainee: Great. And do you have any photos of the accident scene or the damage to your vehicle? SYM: Yes, I took some pictures with my phone. I can send them to you if needed. Trainee: That would be helpful, Pat. Please send the photos to our dedicated claims email address, which is claims@insurance.com. Make sure to include your policy number and a brief description of the accident in the email. SYM: Okay, I'll do that right away. Trainee: Thank you, Pat. Lastly, is there anything else you would like to add or any specific questions you have about the claims process? SYM: Not at the moment. I just want to get my car repaired as soon as possible. SYM: STEP 3 - Setting Expectations. Trainee: Understood, Pat. We will do our best to expedite the claims process for you. Once we receive your email with the photos, an adjuster will be assigned to your case, and they will reach out to you within the next 24 to 48 hours to discuss the next steps. SYM: I appreciate it. Trainee: Is there a preferred phone number or email address where they can contact you? SYM: Yes, they can reach me at (555) 987 - 6543 and my email is pat@email.com. SYM: STEP 4 - Closing. Trainee: Perfect, I have noted down your preferred contact information, and the adjuster will be in touch soon. Thank you for reporting the accident, and we will assist you throughout the entire claims process. If you have any further questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. SYM: Thank you. I appreciate your help. Trainee: You're welcome, Pat. Take care, and we'll be in touch soon. SYM: This concludes your simulation.

extraction.reason: Customer called to file a car insurance claim after a recent accident and sought guidance on next steps and required documentation.
steps: Step 1 - Opening: Greeting and acknowledge the accident, offered to assist with filing the claim.

Step 2 - Gather Information: Collected essential details (name, policy number, date/time of accident, description, safety status, other party's contact and insurance information, vehicle details, and photos). Instructed customer to email photos to claims@insurance.com with policy number and a brief description.

Step 3 - Setting Expectations: Explained the process (an adjuster will be assigned after receiving photos and will contact within 24-48 hours) and confirmed preferred contact methods (phone and email).
Step 4 - Closing: Reconfirmed contact details and reassured that the claims team would assist throughout the process; indicated the adjuster would be in touch.

original_transcript: SYM: Click on the arrow at the side of Interaction Record and click on Internal Commitment SYM: This will open a new style screen. First match the description to the one that shows on the commitment’s matrix. This can be copied and pasted. In this case we will put Priority Services Register. SYM: Select Internal Contact from the Channel/Direction drop down SYM: Select Billing Enquiry from the Type of Contact drop down. The status should remain Open. SYM: The Categorisation needs to be the same as what is advised on Agent Assist for the commitment type you are raising. In this example we are choosing Move In. SYM: Choose Process Move In SYM: Choose Move in completed DD set up SYM: Click on the calendar icon next to received date SYM: This need to be the date you are raising the commitment. In this case the 9th July. SYM: If the Responsible group field has not auto populated click on the two boxes. SYM: Type in the code csc_tsp in the Search term field. SYM: Click Search SYM: Double click on the relevant line. SYM: Click into two squares on Interaction Centre Agent field SYM: Add your last name (agent) into the Last name field - in this case 'Hall' SYM: Add your first name (agent) into the First name field - in this case 'Dawn' SYM: Click Search and double click on your own CPT - in this case CPT-HAD SYM: Under Notes in the box that say’s ‘write note…’ please add a brief note of the conversation and what you have advised the customer. SYM: Once notes are added click Create Internal Commitment. SYM: You are now on the Internal Commitment page. This page is where you select the team the commitment goes too and the instructions that are needed. SYM: Leave the Employee Responsible field blank and click on the 2 boxes at the side of Responsible group SYM: In the Search term box type in the relevant code from the Commitments matrix in this case cbs_dasp SYM: Click Search SYM: Double click on the relevant team you are sending the commitment to. SYM: You can now see the Responsible group field is populated. Now scroll down the page. SYM: In the General Data section, ensure the description and categories are the same as on the commitments matrix. SYM: For this example, choose Category 1 as Social Plan. SYM: For this example, choose DWP instruction. SYM: Click the clock / calendar icon at the side of Commitment Date SYM: Select the correct amount of days / hours the commitment needs to be worked by – in this case 2 working days. SYM: In the 'Write note...' section add the instructions you want carrying out in the commitment. When putting notes on the internal commitment. Please use the commitment matrix for the notes. This helps to give clear request on what action needs to be updated.

extraction.reason: To raise and assign an internal commitment for a Move In (Move in completed DD set up) and document the customer interaction.
steps: Open the Internal Commitment from Interaction Record by clicking the side arrow and selecting Internal Commitment.
Open a new style screen and match the description to the commitment’s matrix; paste the description (e.g., Priority Services Register).
Select Internal Contact from the Channel/Direction drop down.
Select Billing Enquiry from the Type of Contact drop down; keep Status as Open.
Set Categorisation to match the commitment type (Move In) as advised on Agent Assist.
Choose Process Move In.
Choose Move in completed DD set up.
Click the calendar icon next to received date and set it to the date you are raising the commitment (e.g., 9th July).
If the Responsible group field has not auto populated, click on the two boxes to enable auto-population.
Type in the code csc_tsp in the Search term field. Click Search; double click on the relevant line.
Click into two squares on Interaction Centre Agent field; add your last name (e.g., Hall) and first name (e.g., Dawn).
Click Search and double click on your own CPT (e.g., CPT-HAD).
Under Notes in the box that says ‘write note…’ add a brief note of the conversation and what you advised the customer.
Once notes are added click Create Internal Commitment.
You are now on the Internal Commitment page. This page is where you select the team the commitment goes to and the instructions that are needed.
Leave the Employee Responsible field blank and click on the 2 boxes at the side of Responsible group.
In the Search term box type in the relevant code from the Commitments matrix (in this example cbs_dasp).
Click Search; Double click on the relevant team you are sending the commitment to.
You can now see the Responsible group field is populated. Scroll down the page.
In the General Data section, ensure the description and categories are the same as on the commitments matrix.
For this example, choose Category 1 as Social Plan.
For this example, choose DWP instruction.
Click the clock / calendar icon at the side of Commitment Date.
Select the correct amount of days / hours the commitment needs to be worked by (e.g., 2 working days).
In the 'Write note...' section add the instructions you want carrying out in the commitment. When putting notes on the internal commitment, please use the commitment matrix for the notes.

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Northwestern Mutual, Underwriting Case Management, this is ________. How may I help you? SYM: Hi! This is Norm Weston calling from John Barrett's office. This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? Trainee: Hi Norm, may I start with a policy number to get started? SYM: This case for Marty Juana has taken forever, what is the underwriter waiting on? The policy number is T195129. Trainee: Thank you, Norm, I do have Marty's case pulled up here. You would like to talk about what will move this case to approval, is that correct? SYM: Yes, that is what I'm looking for. Trainee: Please give me a moment so I can review the details of the case and see what we can do to get this moving. SYM: Sounds good! Trainee: Thank you so much, I am all up to speed on this case. It looks like we are awaiting records from Dr. Smith's office and that a special authorization was sent to your office by the APS vendor to be reviewed. Do you have a copy of that completed form? SYM: No, I thought you sent it to the client and not just to me. Trainee: Thank you, Norm. Let me take a moment to review the notes from our APS vendor to determine where the document was sent. SYM: Please do, I hope you sent it to the client. Trainee: It doesn't appear that this was sent directly to the client, instead it was sent to your office to facilitate that request. I can have that resent to you right away. SYM: Ok, that is fine. Do you really need these records though? It's been a long time. Trainee: It does look from the notes that the underwriter does require these notes in order to reach the final decision, however, I will put in a note requesting for a risk review and the underwriter will reach out with that information. In the meantime, I'll get the form over to you to reduce any further delay. SYM: That sounds fair. Thank you. Trainee: Of course. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that was all. Trainee: Awesome, well thank you so much for putting your trust in Northwestern Mutual. Have a great rest of your day. SYM: Thank you, you as well!

extraction.reason: To understand why underwriting is taking so long and obtain the missing records/authorization to move toward approval.
steps: Pull up the case using the provided policy number to review the current status and what will move the case toward approval.
Identify the items under review: records from Dr. Smith's office and the special authorization form submitted to the APS vendor.
Review APS vendor notes to determine where the authorization form was sent and confirm it was sent to the office rather than directly to the client.
Offer to resend the completed authorization form to the client to reduce further delay and have it forwarded immediately.
Explain that the underwriter requires the notes to reach a final decision and will initiate a risk review; the underwriter will reach out with the requested information.
Place a note/request for risk review in the case and ensure the form is sent to the client to expedite the process.
Confirm there is nothing else needed at the moment and close the conversation.

original_transcript: Trainee: Carnival Fun Ships, this is [Agent Name]. May I have your name, please? SYM: My name is Alice Test. Trainee: Hi, Alice. Are you currently booked on one of our Fun Ships or working with a Travel Advisor? SYM: No, I’m calling in to see if you can help me plan my cruise. Trainee: I’ll be happy to get your cruise booked today. Trainee: May I have your phone number? SYM: Sure, it is 305-222-3333. Trainee: Thank you! Trainee: What state do you live in? SYM: Florida. Trainee: Thank you. Trainee: Alice, may I have your email address? SYM: Sure! It's alice test@email.com. Trainee: Thank you! May I have your address? SYM: Sure! It's 1 2 3 Maple Street, Miami, Florida, 3 3 1 0 1. Trainee: Thank you. Trainee: Have you cruised with Carnival before? SYM: No, this is my first cruise. Trainee: Welcome to Carnival. I’m so glad you chose to sail with us. Are you celebrating anything special? SYM: I’m just wanting to plan a fun getaway vacation for just myself and my husband. Trainee: Fantastic! So, it sounds like you are looking for one cabin for two guests, right? SYM: Yes. Trainee: Would anyone traveling have the need for special accommodations or is pregnant? SYM: No. Trainee: And to make sure I don’t miss any promotions for you, is anyone traveling an employee of an interline company such as a passenger airline, Amtrak, or UPS or FedEx? SYM: No. Trainee: Anyone serve in the U.S. Armed Forces, Canadian National Defense or over the age of 55? SYM: No, not yet. Trainee: Has your husband sailed with Carnival before? SYM: No. Trainee: And you mentioned earlier, you live in Florida, correct? SYM: Yes Trainee: What ship and sail date have you picked out? SYM: I’m interested in sailing on the Carnival Breeze sailing April 1, 2027. Trainee: I’m glad you are calling in to book today, that’s a popular time to travel over spring break. Bear with me a moment as I pull that up. Trainee: Your cruise will be on the Breeze sailing April 1, 2027, out of the port of Galveston on a 4-day Western Caribbean itinerary. Your boarding time is from 12:30 p.m. to 2:00 p.m. and you will be visiting Cozumel, Mexico with 2 fun days at sea. SYM: Yes, that's the one we want. Trainee: Awesome! Trainee: Your ship, the Breeze, has 14 passenger decks. It has an adult serenity retreat that is only for guests 21 and older where you can sit back, relax, and smell the sea breeze. It also has a seaside theater where you can watch movies under the stars. There are some great additional food options too, like Guy’s Burger Joint, which has the best burgers. SYM: My husband loves burgers. Sounds good! Trainee: Great! Trainee: Things included in your cruise are breakfast, lunch, dinner, snacks, ice cream, pizza, comedy shows, and our amazing stage shows. Not included are our spa treatments, alcoholic beverages, carbonated beverages, gratuities, and if you want to try your luck in our casino at sea. SYM: This sounds perfect for us. Trainee: Great! Now, let’s find you the best deal for your cruise. Trainee: We have a lot of great promotions. I’m seeing the best promotion for you today is our Early Saver Promotion. Trainee: The Early Saver promotion guarantees you the lowest rate from the day that you book all the way until two business days prior to your sailing. If at any time the rate drops below what you booked at, you can fill out a price protection form online and have the balance adjusted before final payment or get the difference as an onboard credit after final. Keep in mind this promotion does not allow name changes and if you cancel or move your sailing prior to final payment date it’s only $50 per person fee and the rest of the money gets put towards a future cruise credit which you have 12 months to use. SYM: Okay. Trainee: What kind of cabin would you prefer? They're all very spacious. We have an interior cabin with no windows, an Ocean View with a big picture window, a Balcony cabin that gives you both a window and your own private balcony, and our largest option - a Suite, which has even more space and a balcony. SYM: We would like to have a Balcony cabin. Trainee: Great choice! That’s my favorite, too. Trainee: I’m looking forward to finding you a great balcony. Trainee: I found a great cabin for you. It’s on our Lido Deck, Deck 10. There are only 4 cabins left that accommodate 2 guests on this deck so I’m glad you called in today. This will put you in the middle of the ship. Let’s look at the details about your cabin. Trainee: Your cabin has 220 square feet, two twin size beds that will convert to a king for you, and your own private balcony. One of the best things about a balcony is how you can enjoy your morning coffee or a glass of wine at night while you enjoy the sounds, smell, and view of the ocean from your own private balcony. SYM: Sounds perfect for us. Trainee: Awesome, let me get the pricing for your cabin. Trainee: Your cabin is only an average rate of $829 per person including taxes and fees based upon 2 guests in the cabin. Carnival Vacation Protection is $190 for the cabin, giving you a total of $1848.00. Trainee: All we need to get started today is a small deposit of $340, which includes activation of your Carnival Vacation Protection. The remaining balance won't be due until your final payment date of 1/16/2027. Would you like to book this with early, late or your-time dining? SYM: Let’s book for a late dining. Trainee: Wonderful! Trainee: One moment while I grab your cabin. Trainee: I have the perfect cabin for you, cabin number 10277. Trainee: After this call, you will receive an email confirmation. Please read the terms and conditions of your email cruise ticket contract, as you are legally bound by the terms. SYM: Okay. Trainee: May I have each name as it appears on their travel documents? SYM: Alice Test 05/14/1985 and James Test 9/24/1984. Trainee: Thank you! Just to confirm, that was Alice Test with date of birth 05/14/1985 and you said it was your husband traveling with you, James Test, with his date of birth 9/24/1984? SYM: That is correct. Trainee: Is everyone traveling a U.S. Citizen and U.S. Resident? SYM: Yes, we are. Trainee: Thank you! Trainee: And you mentioned earlier you both live in Florida, correct? SYM: Correct. Trainee: Would you like to go ahead and include your prepaid gratuities, or will you be taking care of that onboard? SYM: I think I’ll handle that onboard. Trainee: Okay, thanks! Trainee: I selected your dinner time as Late Dining as you requested earlier. SYM: Great! Trainee: Please choose a 4-digit pin number that is easy for you to remember for security purposes. SYM: How about 2 4 8 7. Trainee: 2487, got it! Trainee: And to confirm does anyone traveling have a special need or pregnant? SYM: No Trainee: And you mentioned earlier you were sailing for a fun get away. No special occasions, right? SYM: Correct, not this time. This time it is just for fun. Trainee: Thank you! Trainee: May I have your email address so we can contact you in case of itinerary changes or voyage delays?​ SYM: Let’s use my same email earlier for me at alice test @ email.com and james test @ email.com for my husband.​ Trainee: Thank you! Trainee: May I have an alternate contact telephone number? SYM: Sure, my cell phone is 305-222-3333. Trainee: Thank you! Would you like a text to be sent to your mobile number for all sailing changes and payment reminders? SYM: Yes, please. Trainee: Bear with me a moment as I finish creating your booking. SYM: Okay. Trainee: I’m almost done. I’m just putting some additional notes on your booking. Trainee: Your booking number is X9SN55. You are sailing on the Breeze doing a 4-day Western Caribbean itinerary. We have you in that amazing balcony cabin, 10277. The total cost of your cruise is $1848 with only your deposit of $340 due today. Trainee: Are you taking care of this payment now or would you like to hear more about our partner, Flex Pay, where you could book this for as little as $0 down and pay for up to 24 months with affordable rates? SYM: I’m going to use my Visa Card. Trainee: Okay, great! Trainee: May I have the name of the card holder? SYM: It’s my name on the card.​ Alice Test. Trainee: May I have the expiration date and billing zip code? SYM: It is April 2028, and my zip code is 3 3 1 3 3. Trainee: Thank you, I have April 2028 and zip code of 33133, correct? SYM: Yes. Trainee: Would you like to pay just the deposit of $340 today? SYM: Yes, the deposit only. Trainee: As a courtesy for you, we can go ahead and set up Auto Pay for you interest free and split your final payment amount into equal amounts of $71.81 starting on May 1, 2025. Would you like to go ahead and take advantage of this? SYM: Yes, let’s go ahead and set that up. Trainee: Okay, perfect. Trainee: Now that I’ve verified the name of the cardholder, expiration date, zip code, and payment amount, I will be placing you into Secure Mode where I will prompt you to enter your credit card number. ​ ​ Trainee: During this time, you will be able to hear me, however, I will not be able to hear you. It is important that when entering your credit card number, you are not using speakerphone or a Bluetooth device. ​ Trainee: After you input your credit card number, Secure Mode will drop, and our call will reconnect, allowing me to hear you again. Then, I can verify payment. Do you have your credit card ready? SYM: Yes. Trainee: Do you have any questions before I place you into Secure Mode?​ SYM: No. Trainee: You are now in Secure Mode. Please enter your credit card information. Trainee: Thank you for your payment of $340.00. Before I submit, are the last few digits 4444? SYM: Yes. Trainee: I see your payment of $340.00 has processed. Trainee: I am going to send your cabin confirmation now. Trainee: You are all set. Keep in mind that adding or removing a guest will change the average rate per person. Please refer to your confirmation that I am emailing you now or you can go on the website to carnival.com/bookedguest for your electronic documents, boarding pass, travel docs, and penalty information. SYM: Okay. Trainee: Proper travel documentation is due upon embarkation and Carnival highly recommends a passport. Trainee: Is there anything else I can help you with today? SYM: That’s all. Trainee: Super! As a reminder, you will be receiving an email survey about my service today. I appreciate your feedback. SYM: Sure, you really made this whole process very easy. Trainee: Thank you for choosing Carnival and you have a Funtastic day!

extraction.reason: To plan and book a Carnival cruise for two adults (4-day Western Caribbean on Carnival Breeze, balcony cabin).
steps: Collected caller details (name, phone, state, email, address) and confirmed the goal to plan a cruise.

original_transcript: SYM: In this sym, we will review how the UCSL application varies based on state. SYM: Reminder that we can not C O P whole life applications for Connecticut or Montana. SYM: New York has its own application for our Guaranteed Whole Life policy. We’ll go into detail on New York later. SYM: The states in red on the map have some different verbatim messages that will appear in the e App. SYM: Remember that these boxes are verbatim statements. SYM: You should not try to memorize these, as they may change for each state. SYM: Always be sure to read what's on your screen word for word. SYM: One such example is with California, the final application verbatim has an additional paragraph regarding fraud. SYM: This allows us to be compliant with California law. The fraud statement is also provided in the policy documents. SYM: Again, this is why you should not memorize verbatims. Simply follow the application. SYM: Another California law requires we obtain an email address from our California elders (which is age 65 or older) so we can send them pertinent disclosures before the application is completed. SYM: To comply with the California law, there is a verbatim early in the application regarding consent to electronic delivery and e-signature. SYM: The verbatim and email address field is mandatory, and the e-app will prevent you from continuing the application if you do not enter in a valid customer email address. SYM: Once you have entered the email address in the box you must press the Send button. If you don’t press this button, the e-app will prevent you from continuing the application. SYM: If the email fails to send, the Send button will turn red and will say Fail. SYM: The e-app will prevent you from moving forward until an email has successfully been sent. SYM: If the email successfully sends, the Send button will turn green and will say Sent. SYM: Once you have received the green Sent message, you need to ask the customer to verbally confirm they received the email. SYM: This is what the email that the customer receives looks like. SYM: Here’s another question that will only appear during the application in certain states. SYM: These states have state special questions and verbiage that is required to be read about accessing PDF files via the internet and providing their consent to receive electronic documents. SYM: The state requires we review this electronic consent. SYM: We're asking if they can access the internet in any shape or form. SYM: If they say no, you can clarify by asking if they have access to the internet (smart phone, library, etc.). SYM: If they still answer No, you will need to explain to the applicant that if they are not able to access the internet, or do not provide their consent, you will not be able to take their application over the phone and it will need to be mailed to them. This may delay the processing time and the effective date of their policy. SYM: Let’s practice a state specific scenario! Click the arrow when you are ready to begin. Trainee: Have you received an application packet? SYM: No. Trainee: Are you able to open, view and save P D F files via the internet? SYM: No. Trainee: Do you have access to the internet by using a smart phone or going to the library? SYM: Oh, yes. I can do that. Trainee: I am required to obtain your consent for the delivery of electronic documents to you whether through the internet, email, web, text, instant message, digital media or the like. Your consent applies to all documents Mutual of Omaha may be required to deliver to you in writing. Any document provided to you electronically may be provided in paper upon your request. You may withdraw your consent at any time. If you withdraw your consent, I will not be able to complete your application over the phone and I will need to mail you a paper application. You may withdraw your consent, update your contact information or obtain a paper copy of any document for no charge, by contacting (800) 775-6000. You will need access to a computer or other device which provides internet access or email, as well as the ability to open, view and save a PDF, text or html file. Trainee: Do I have your consent to provide you with the necessary documents electronically? SYM: Yes Trainee: Disclosures are made available to you at the following website: http://www.mutualofomaha.com/wholelifedocuments SYM: Great job practicing one of those state specific items in the e App. SYM: What did we learn today? Take a moment to review some of the key learnings from this sym. SYM: Click the lightbulb when you are ready to continue. SYM: Understanding that the e App will vary by state ensures compliance with state-specific rules and regulations, helping us navigate the process accurately and effectively.

extraction.reason: Assistance with state-specific electronic delivery of documents and consent for the e-app, including internet access requirements and California rules.
steps: Acknowledge that the e-App varies by state and emphasize reading the screen verbatim rather than memorizing verbatims.
Explain California-specific requirements (fraud statement in the final application and mandatory elder email address) and other state-specific electronic delivery rules.
Describe the e-app’s email-delivery controls: enter a valid email, press Send, and that the app will not proceed until the email is successfully sent.
Explain email status indicators: if sending fails (Send turns red, displays Fail) and the app prevents proceeding until success; if sent (Send turns green, displays Sent), proceed to the next step.
Instruct to verbally confirm with the customer once the email has been successfully sent and received.

If the customer cannot access the internet, explain that the application cannot be completed over the phone and must be mailed, which may delay processing and the policy’s effective date.
Present the formal electronic-consent language to obtain the customer’s consent to deliver documents electronically, including scope, withdrawal rights, and contact information (800-775-6000).
Reiterate the technical requirements (internet access or email, ability to open/save PDFs) and obtain explicit consent to electronic delivery.
Conduct a practice scenario to reinforce understanding of state-specific requirements and the e-App workflow, and review key learnings.

original_transcript: SYM: Hello! If you are starting this sym, that means you chose the Empathy Close as the technique you would like to try on your calls. ​ If you wanted to try a different closing technique, now is the time to exit this sym and head to the one you wanted to practice. SYM: Here are a few tips for how to navigate throughout this Sym. Click the arrow when you’re ready to continue.​ SYM: As reviewed earlier, the Empathy Close technique focuses on the customer’s perspective and feelings and leaning into those emotions to show how the product will help them.​ SYM: Here’s an example of how an empathy close might sound.​ SYM: I know you’re concerned about having this in place for your loved ones so it will just take a few minutes to get you covered today. ​ SYM: Remember, we are going to ask for the sale immediately after providing the price.​ This is why a best practice during the discover process is to ask the budget question last to put yourself in a better position to successfully close because you have all your information you need to know to offer the right product based on the customers needs. SYM: Here are some more examples of an Empathy Close. ​ SYM: PRICE. I know you’re concerned about having this in place for your loved ones so it will just take a few minutes to get you covered today. ​ SYM: PRICE, And I realize it has been difficult to find something that works for you, but I believe this will. It will only take a few more minutes to get you covered today.​ SYM: Notice that something they have in common is making the sale today.​ They also reference back to something that was discovered about the customer earlier in the call.​ SYM: These examples are in other people’s words, take a moment to write down how you would word your empathy close.​ SYM: Again, let's say you’ve completed the discovery process with Sonya and have determined that an $8,000 UCSL policy will best meet her needs.​ SYM: Take a moment to review the information and write down an Empathy Close you could use for Sonya.​ Remember, you should ask for the sale immediately after providing the price. SYM: Click the “I’m Ready!” icon when you are ready to practice your empathy close.​ Trainee: ... SYM: Great job practicing your Empathy Close. SYM: I realize practicing new techniques can be a challenge, but it takes practice to get comfortable. Great job practicing this technique today, try it out on your next call to close the sale – you got this!​

extraction.reason: The customer called to get help purchasing or securing an insurance policy (UCSL) to cover loved ones.
steps: Confirmed the Empathy Close technique as the chosen method and offered an option to exit to a different closing technique if desired
Explained the Empathy Close concept, focusing on the customer's feelings and how the product helps them/their loved ones
Provided example lines for the empathy close, including references to cherishing loved ones and taking a few minutes to get coverage
Advised on closing sequence: plan to ask for the sale immediately after presenting the price
Suggested best practice to place budget questions last, to position for a successful close after gathering needs
Presented additional Empathy Close variations and noted the importance of referencing information discovered earlier on the call
Created a concrete scenario (Sonya with an $8,000 UCSL policy) and guided drafting an Empathy Close tailored to that scenario
Encouraged the trainee to review the gathered information and write their own Empathy Close for Sonya
Prompted the trainee to click 'I'm Ready!' to practice, followed by positive reinforcement and encouragement after practice

extraction.reason: Customer wanted to set up an automated birthday gift for their sponsored child (they believed it was already set up) and to process a gift for today since they missed the birthday.
steps: Verified sponsor identity by requesting sponsor number and confirming the account holder's name
Opened the sponsor's Compassion account and identified the two children (Jim from Peru and Michael from Rwanda) and reviewed birthday gift settings
Determined that an automated birthday gift was not configured on the account (only the monthly sponsorship withdrawal existed)
Asked for payment method details and confirmed the card ending in 5252 to use for the gift
Set up an automated birthday gift of $40 annually and processed a one-time birthday gift of $40 for today to cover the missed date
Explained processing timeline (2–3 months before the gift reaches the child) and identified the next automated gift date (November 17, 2024)
Clarified which child(s) would receive the gift and acknowledged prior activity (an automated gift for Peru existed previously and a one-time gift in May 2023), ensuring correct ongoing setup
Confirmed that the automated gift is now active and asked if any further assistance was needed

original_transcript: Trainee: Thank you for calling Barnes and Noble. My name is (Your Name). How can I help you? SYM: Hi. I placed an order and wanted to know the status. I should have received my order by now. I really need the books to give them as a gift next week. Trainee: I'm sorry you haven't received your order. I would be happy to check the status of your order. Can I have your order number, please? SYM: My order number is 4 1 3 6 3 3 3 9 3 0. Trainee: Thank you. One moment while I locate your order. SYM: No problem. I appreciate it. Trainee: Can I have you verify your email address, please? SYM: Sure. My email address is anita napp at gmail.com. Trainee: Great, thanks! What is your shipping address, please? SYM: My address is 5 7 2 Angel Place, Sunny, California 9 0 2 1 0. Trainee: Thank you. Just a moment please, while I research your order. Trainee: Thank you for your patience. I can see your order shipped on January 17th and was expected to be delivered by January 24th. One moment while I review the tracking details. SYM: Okay, thanks. I appreciate your help. Trainee: Thank you for your patience. I've checked the tracking, and I can see that is was delivered on January 24th. Have you checked your mailbox and all of the doors? SYM: Yes. I checked everywhere, and I still can't find the package. Trainee: I'm going to consider your order lost in transit. Give me a moment while I check the available options. SYM: Sure. Trainee: Great news! I have the items in stock, and can have your order replaced free of charge. Would you like me to replace them? SYM: Yes, I want them replaced. I need them for a gift next week. Trainee: Absolutely! Due to the inconvenience, I will upgrade the shipping level as well. SYM: Ok, thanks! That would be great, and will help so much! Trainee: Of course. It's my pleasure since you didn't receive them. Trainee: Are there any changes to the delivery address that we need to make? SYM: No, it will go to the same address, but can you add apartment B onto the shipping address? Trainee: Yes, I can update the address to include your apartment number. Trainee: The expected delivery date for your order would be on Friday, February 3rd. SYM: Ok, sounds good. That should be before the party. Trainee: You'll receive an email confirming the order shortly. You will also receive a shipping confirmation email when the order ships, which includes tracking information. Trainee: Your new order number is 6180000649. I will also email you a return label in case you receive the original and the replacement. SYM: I just received the first email. Thank you. Trainee: You're welcome. Is there anything else I can assist you with? SYM: No, that's it. Thanks! Trainee: Thank you! Have a great day, and thanks for calling Barnes and Noble.

extraction.reason: Customer asked for the status of a previously shipped order and to replace a lost-in-transit shipment that was needed as a gift next week.
steps: Agent introduced themselves and offered to check the order status.
Asked for the order number and verified it.
Verified the customer's email address and shipping address.
Located the order in the system and checked shipping and tracking details.
Confirmed the order shipped on Jan 17 and was expected by Jan 24, then noted it was delivered on Jan 24.
Informed the customer that the package couldn't be found after delivery and that it would be treated as lost in transit.
Offered to replace the items free of charge due to the inconvenience; the customer consented.
Upgraded the shipping level for the replacement.
Asked to confirm delivery address changes; added apartment number to the address.
Provided the new estimated delivery date for the replacement (Feb 3).
Advised that confirmation emails would be sent and that a shipping confirmation with tracking would follow.
Issued a new replacement order number (6180000649) and offered to send a return label in case the original package is found.
Customer acknowledged receiving the initial email; closed with offer of further assistance if needed.
